1.1: Many have attempted to write about what had taken place among us.
1.2: They received their information from those who had been eyewitnesses and servants of God’s word from the beginning, and they passed it on to us.
1.3: I, too, have followed everything closely from the beginning. So I thought it would be a good idea to write an orderly account for Your Excellency, Theophilus.
1.4: In this way you will know that what you’ve been told is true.
1.5: When Herod was king of Judea, there was a priest named Zechariah, who belonged to the division of priests named after Abijah. Zechariah’s wife Elizabeth was a descendant of Aaron.
1.6: Zechariah and Elizabeth had God’s approval. They followed all the Lord’s commands and regulations perfectly.
1.7: Yet, they never had any children because Elizabeth couldn’t become pregnant. Both of them were too old to have children.
1.8: Zechariah was on duty with his division of priests. As he served in God’s presence,
1.9: he was chosen by priestly custom to go into the Lord’s temple to burn incense.
1.10: All the people were praying outside while he was burning incense.
1.11: Then, to the right of the incense altar, an angel of the Lord appeared to him.
1.12: Zechariah was troubled and overcome with fear.
1.13: The angel said to him, “Don’t be afraid, Zechariah! God has heard your prayer. Your wife Elizabeth will have a son, and you will name him John.
1.14: He will be your pride and joy, and many people will be glad that he was born.
1.15: As far as the Lord is concerned, he will be a great man. He will never drink wine or any other liquor. He will be filled with the Holy Spirit even before he is born.
1.16: He will bring many people in Israel back to the Lord their God.
1.17: He will go ahead of the Lord with the spirit and power that Elijah had. He will change parents’ attitudes toward their children. He will change disobedient people so that they will accept the wisdom of those who have God’s approval. In this way he will prepare the people for their Lord.”
1.18: Zechariah said to the angel, “What proof is there for this? I’m an old man, and my wife is beyond her childbearing years.”
1.19: The angel answered him, “I’m Gabriel! I stand in God’s presence. God sent me to tell you this good news.
1.20: But because you didn’t believe what I said, you will be unable to talk until the day this happens. Everything will come true at the right time.”
1.21: Meanwhile, the people were waiting for Zechariah. They were amazed that he was staying in the temple so long.
1.22: When he did come out, he was unable to speak to them. So they realized that he had seen a vision in the temple. He motioned to them but remained unable to talk.
1.23: When the days of his service were over, he went home.
1.24: Later, his wife Elizabeth became pregnant and didn’t go out in public for five months. She said,
1.25: “The Lord has done this for me now. He has removed my public disgrace.”
1.26: Six months after Elizabeth had become pregnant, God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a city in Galilee.
1.27: The angel went to a virgin promised in marriage to a descendant of David named Joseph. The virgin’s name was Mary.
1.28: When the angel entered her home, he greeted her and said, “You are favored by the Lord! The Lord is with you.”
1.29: She was startled by what the angel said and tried to figure out what this greeting meant.
1.30:
The angel told her,
“Don’t be afraid, Mary. You have found favor with God.
1.31:
You will become pregnant, give birth to a son,
    and name him Yeshua.
1.32:
He will be a great man
    and will be called the Son of the Most High.
    The Lord God will give him
    the throne of his ancestor David.
1.33:
Your son will be king of Jacob’s people forever,
    and his kingdom will never end.”
1.34: Mary asked the angel, “How can this be? I’ve never had sexual intercourse.”
1.35: The angel answered her, “The Holy Spirit will come to you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. Therefore, the holy child developing inside you will be called the Son of God.
1.36: “Elizabeth, your relative, is six months pregnant with a son in her old age. People said she couldn’t have a child.
1.37: But nothing is impossible for God.”
1.38:
Mary answered, “I am the Lord’s servant. Let everything you’ve said happen to me.”
Then the angel left her.
1.39: Soon afterward, Mary hurried to a city in the mountain region of Judah.
1.40: She entered Zechariah’s home and greeted Elizabeth.
1.41: When Elizabeth heard the greeting, she felt the baby kick. Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit.
1.42: She said in a loud voice, “You are the most blessed of all women, and blessed is the child that you will have.
1.43: I feel blessed that the mother of my Lord is visiting me.
1.44: As soon as I heard your greeting, I felt the baby jump for joy.
1.45: You are blessed for believing that the Lord would keep his promise to you.”
1.46:
Mary said,
“My soul praises the Lord’s greatness!
1.47: My spirit finds its joy in God, my Savior,
1.48:
because he has looked favorably on me, his humble servant.
“From now on, all people will call me blessed
1.49:
because the Almighty has done great things to me.
    His name is holy.
1.50:
For those who fear him,
    his mercy lasts throughout every generation.
1.51:
“He displayed his mighty power.
    He scattered those who think too highly of themselves.
1.52:
He pulled strong rulers from their thrones.
    He honored humble people.
1.53:
He fed hungry people with good food.
    He sent rich people away with nothing.
1.54: “He remembered to help his servant Israel forever.
1.55:
This is the promise he made to our ancestors,
    to Abraham and his descendants.”
1.56: Mary stayed with Elizabeth about three months and then went back home.
1.57: When the time came for Elizabeth to have her child, she gave birth to a son.
1.58: Her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had been very kind to her, and they shared her joy.
1.59: When the child was eight days old, they went to the temple to circumcise him. They were going to name him Zechariah after his father.
1.60: But his mother spoke up, “Absolutely not! His name will be John.”
1.61: Their friends said to her, “But you don’t have any relatives with that name.”
1.62: So they motioned to the baby’s father to see what he wanted to name the child.
1.63: Zechariah asked for a writing tablet and wrote, “His name is John.” Everyone was amazed.
1.64: Suddenly, Zechariah was able to speak, and he began to praise God.
1.65: All their neighbors were filled with awe. Throughout the mountain region of Judea, people talked about everything that had happened.
1.66: Everyone who heard about it seriously thought it over and asked, “What does the future hold for this child?” It was clear that the Lord was with him.
1.67: His father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit and prophesied,
1.68:
“Praise the Lord God of Israel!
    He has come to take care of his people
        and to set them free.
1.69:
He has raised up a mighty Savior for us
    in the family of his servant David.
1.70: He made this promise through his holy prophets long ago.
1.71:
He promised to save us from our enemies
    and from the power of all who hate us.
1.72:
He has shown his mercy to our ancestors
    and remembered his holy promise,
1.73: the oath that he swore to our ancestor Abraham.
1.74:
He promised to rescue us from our enemies’ power
    so that we could serve him without fear
1.75: by being holy and honorable as long as we live.
1.76:
“You, child, will be called a prophet of the Most High.
    You will go ahead of the Lord to prepare his way.
1.77:
You will make his people know that they can be saved
    through the forgiveness of their sins.
1.78:
A new day will dawn on us from above
    because our God is loving and merciful.
1.79:
He will give light to those who live in the dark
    and in death’s shadow.
    He will guide us into the way of peace.”
1.80: The child John grew and became spiritually strong. He lived in the desert until the day he appeared to the people of Israel.

2.1: At that time the Emperor Augustus ordered a census of the Roman Empire.
2.2: This was the first census taken while Quirinius was governor of Syria.
2.3: All the people went to register in the cities where their ancestors had lived.
2.4: So Joseph went from Nazareth, a city in Galilee, to a Judean city called Bethlehem. Joseph, a descendant of King David, went to Bethlehem because David had been born there.
2.5: Joseph went there to register with Mary. She had been promised to him in marriage and was pregnant.
2.6: While they were in Bethlehem, the time came for Mary to have her child.
2.7: She gave birth to her firstborn son. She wrapped him in strips of cloth and laid him in a manger because there wasn’t any room for them in the inn.
2.8: Shepherds were in the fields near Bethlehem. They were taking turns watching their flock during the night.
2.9: An angel from the Lord suddenly appeared to them. The glory of the Lord filled the area with light, and they were terrified.
2.10: The angel said to them, “Don’t be afraid! I have good news for you, a message that will fill everyone with joy.
2.11: Today your Savior, Christ the Lord, was born in David’s city.
2.12: This is how you will recognize him: You will find an infant wrapped in strips of cloth and lying in a manger.”
2.13: Suddenly, a large army of angels appeared with the angel. They were praising God by saying,
2.14:
“Glory to God in the highest heaven,
    and on earth peace to those who have his good will!”
2.15: The angels left them and went back to heaven. The shepherds said to each other, “Let’s go to Bethlehem and see what the Lord has told us about.”
2.16: They went quickly and found Mary and Joseph with the baby, who was lying in a manger.
2.17: When they saw the child, they repeated what they had been told about him.
2.18: Everyone who heard the shepherds’ story was amazed.
2.19: Mary treasured all these things in her heart and always thought about them.
2.20: As the shepherds returned to their flock, they glorified and praised God for everything they had seen and heard. Everything happened the way the angel had told them.
2.21: Eight days after his birth, the child was circumcised and named Yeshua. This was the name the angel had given him before his mother became pregnant.
2.22: After the days required by Moses’ Teachings to make a mother clean had passed, Joseph and Mary went to Jerusalem. They took Yeshua to present him to the Lord.
2.23: They did exactly what was written in the Lord’s Teachings: “Every firstborn boy is to be set apart as holy to the Lord.”
2.24: They also offered a sacrifice as required by the Lord’s Teachings: “a pair of mourning doves or two young pigeons.”
2.25: A man named Simeon was in Jerusalem. He lived an honorable and devout life. He was waiting for the one who would comfort Israel. The Holy Spirit was with Simeon
2.26: and had told him that he wouldn’t die until he had seen the Messiah, whom the Lord would send.
2.27: Moved by the Spirit, Simeon went into the temple courtyard. Mary and Joseph were bringing the child Yeshua into the courtyard at the same time. They brought him so that they could do for him what Moses’ Teachings required.
2.28: Then Simeon took the child in his arms and praised God by saying,
2.29:
“Now, Lord, you are allowing your servant to leave in peace
    as you promised.
2.30: My eyes have seen your salvation,
2.31: which you have prepared for all people to see.
2.32:
He is a light that will reveal salvation to the nations
    and bring glory to your people Israel.”
2.33: Yeshua’s father and mother were amazed at what was said about him.
2.34: Then Simeon blessed them and said to Mary, his mother, “This child is the reason that many people in Israel will be condemned and many others will be saved. He will be a sign that will expose
2.35: the thoughts of those who reject him. And a sword will pierce your heart.”
2.36: Anna, a prophet, was also there. She was a descendant of Phanuel from the tribe of Asher. She was now very old. Her husband had died seven years after they were married,
2.37: and she had been a widow for 84 years. Anna never left the temple courtyard but worshiped day and night by fasting and praying.
2.38: At that moment she came up to Mary and Joseph and began to thank God. She spoke about Yeshua to all who were waiting for Jerusalem to be set free.
2.39: After doing everything the Lord’s Teachings required, Joseph and Mary returned to their hometown of Nazareth in Galilee.
2.40: The child grew and became strong. He was filled with wisdom, and God’s favor was with him.
2.41: Every year Yeshua’s parents would go to Jerusalem for the Passover festival.
2.42: When he was 12 years old, they went as usual.
2.43: When the festival was over, they left for home. The boy Yeshua stayed behind in Jerusalem, but his parents didn’t know it.
2.44: They thought that he was with the others who were traveling with them. After traveling for a day, they started to look for him among their relatives and friends.
2.45: When they didn’t find him, they went back to Jerusalem to look for him.
2.46: Three days later, they found him in the temple courtyard. He was sitting among the teachers, listening to them, and asking them questions.
2.47: His understanding and his answers stunned everyone who heard him.
2.48: When his parents saw him, they were shocked. His mother asked him, “Son, why have you done this to us? Your father and I have been worried sick looking for you!”
2.49: Yeshua said to them, “Why were you looking for me? Didn’t you realize that I had to be in my Father’s house?”
2.50: But they didn’t understand what he meant.
2.51:
Then he returned with them to Nazareth and was obedient to them.
His mother treasured all these things in her heart.
2.52: Yeshua grew in wisdom and maturity. He gained favor from God and people.

3.1: It was the fifteenth year in the reign of the Emperor Tiberius. Pontius Pilate was governor of Judea. Herod ruled Galilee, and his brother Philip ruled Iturea and Trachonitis. Lysanias was the ruler of Abilene.
3.2: It was at the time when Annas and Caiaphas were chief priests that God spoke to John, son of Zechariah, in the desert.
3.3: John traveled throughout the region around the Jordan River. He told people about a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.
3.4:
As the prophet Isaiah wrote in his book,
“A voice cries out in the desert:
    ‘Prepare the way for the Lord!
    Make his paths straight!
3.5:
Every valley will be filled.
        Every mountain and hill will be leveled.
            The crooked ways will be made straight.
            The rough roads will be made smooth.
3.6: All people will see the salvation that God gives.’”
3.7: Crowds of people were coming to be baptized by John. He would say to them, “You poisonous snakes! Who showed you how to flee from God’s coming anger?
3.8: Do those things that prove that you have turned to God and have changed the way you think and act. Don’t say, ‘Abraham is our ancestor.’ I guarantee that God can raise up descendants for Abraham from these stones.
3.9: The ax is now ready to cut the roots of the trees. Any tree that doesn’t produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into a fire.”
3.10: The crowds asked him, “What should we do?”
3.11: He answered them, “Whoever has two shirts should share with the person who doesn’t have any. Whoever has food should share it too.”
3.12: Some tax collectors came to be baptized. They asked him, “Teacher, what should we do?”
3.13: He told them, “Don’t collect more money than you are ordered to collect.”
3.14:
Some soldiers asked him, “And what should we do?”
He told them, “Be satisfied with your pay, and never use threats or blackmail to get money from anyone.”
3.15: People’s hopes were rising as they all wondered whether John was the Messiah.
3.16: John replied to all of them, “I baptize you with water. But the one who is more powerful than I is coming. I am not worthy to untie his sandal straps. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and fire.
3.17: His winnowing shovel is in his hand to clean up his threshing floor. He will gather the wheat into his barn, but he will burn the husks in a fire that can never be put out.”
3.18: With many other encouraging words, he told the Good News to the people.
3.19: John spoke out against the ruler Herod because Herod had married his own sister-in-law, Herodias. He also spoke out against Herod for all the evil things he had done.
3.20: So Herod added one more evil to all the others; he locked John in prison.
3.21: When all the people were baptized, Yeshua, too, was baptized. While he was praying, heaven opened,
3.22: and the Holy Spirit came down to him in the form of a dove. A voice from heaven said, “You are my Son, whom I love. I am pleased with you.”
3.23:
Yeshua was about 30 years old when he began his ministry.
Yeshua, so people thought, was the son of Joseph, son of Eli,
3.24: son of Matthat, son of Levi, son of Melchi, son of Jannai, son of Joseph,
3.25: son of Mattathias, son of Amos, son of Nahum, son of Esli, son of Naggai,
3.26: son of Maath, son of Mattathias, son of Semein, son of Josech, son of Joda,
3.27: son of Joanan, son of Rhesa, son of Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, son of Neri,
3.28: son of Melchi, son of Addi, son of Cosam, son of Elmadam, son of Er,
3.29: son of Joshua, son of Eliezer, son of Jorim, son of Matthat, son of Levi,
3.30: son of Simeon, son of Judah, son of Joseph, son of Jonam, son of Eliakim,
3.31: son of Melea, son of Menna, son of Mattatha, son of Nathan, son of David,
3.32: son of Jesse, son of Obed, son of Boaz, son of Salmon, son of Nahshon,
3.33: son of Amminadab, son of Admin, son of Arni, son of Hezron, son of Perez, son of Judah,
3.34: son of Jacob, son of Isaac, son of Abraham, son of Terah, son of Nahor,
3.35: son of Serug, son of Reu, son of Peleg, son of Eber, son of Shelah,

4.1: Yeshua was filled with the Holy Spirit as he left the Jordan River. The Spirit led him while he was in the desert,
4.2: where he was tempted by the devil for 40 days. During those days Yeshua ate nothing, so when they were over, he was hungry.
4.3: The devil said to him, “If you are the Son of God, tell this stone to become a loaf of bread.”
4.4: Yeshua answered him, “Scripture says, ‘A person cannot live on bread alone.’”
4.5: The devil took him to a high place and showed him all the kingdoms of the world in an instant.
4.6: The devil said to him, “I will give you all the power and glory of these kingdoms. All of it has been given to me, and I give it to anyone I please.
4.7: So if you will worship me, all this will be yours.”
4.8: Yeshua answered him, “Scripture says, ‘Worship the Lord your God and serve only him.’”
4.9: Then the devil took him into Jerusalem and had him stand on the highest part of the temple. He said to Yeshua, “If you are the Son of God, jump from here!
4.10: Scripture says, ‘He will put his angels in charge of you to watch over you carefully.
4.11: They will carry you in their hands so that you never hit your foot against a rock.’”
4.12: Yeshua answered him, “It has been said, ‘Never tempt the Lord your God.’”
4.13: After the devil had finished tempting Yeshua in every possible way, the devil left him until another time.
4.14: Yeshua returned to Galilee. The power of the Spirit was with him, and the news about him spread throughout the surrounding country.
4.15: He taught in the synagogues, and everyone praised him.
4.16: Then Yeshua came to Nazareth, where he had been brought up. As usual he went into the synagogue on the day of worship. He stood up to read the lesson.
4.17: The attendant gave him the book of the prophet Isaiah. He opened it and found the place where it read:
4.18:
“The Spirit of the Lord is with me.
    He has anointed me
        to tell the Good News to the poor.
    He has sent me
        to announce forgiveness to the prisoners of sin
            and the restoring of sight to the blind,
        to forgive those who have been shattered by sin,
4.19: to announce the year of the Lord’s favor.”
4.20: Yeshua closed the book, gave it back to the attendant, and sat down. Everyone in the synagogue watched him closely.
4.21: Then he said to them, “This passage came true today when you heard me read it.”
4.22: All the people spoke well of him. They were amazed to hear the gracious words flowing from his lips. They said, “Isn’t this Joseph’s son?”
4.23: So he said to them, “You’ll probably quote this proverb to me, ‘Doctor, cure yourself!’ and then say to me, ‘Do all the things in your hometown that we’ve heard you’ve done in Capernaum.’”
4.24: Then Yeshua added, “I can guarantee this truth: A prophet isn’t accepted in his hometown.
4.25: “I can guarantee this truth: There were many widows in Israel in Elijah’s time. It had not rained for three-and-a-half years, and the famine was severe everywhere in the country.
4.26: But God didn’t send Elijah to anyone except a widow at Zarephath in the territory of Sidon.
4.27: There were also many people with skin diseases in Israel in the prophet Elisha’s time. But God cured no one except Naaman from Syria.”
4.28: Everyone in the synagogue became furious when they heard this.
4.29: Their city was built on a hill with a cliff. So they got up, forced Yeshua out of the city, and led him to the cliff. They intended to throw him off of it.
4.30: But Yeshua walked right by them and went away.
4.31: Yeshua went to Capernaum, a city in Galilee, and taught them on a day of worship.
4.32: The people were amazed at his teachings because he spoke with authority.
4.33: In the synagogue was a man possessed by a spirit, an evil demon. He shouted very loudly,
4.34: “Oh, no! What do you want with us, Yeshua from Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are—the Holy One of God!”
4.35: Yeshua ordered the spirit, “Keep quiet, and come out of him!” The demon threw the man down in the middle of the synagogue and came out without hurting him.
4.36: Everyone was stunned. They said to one another, “What kind of command is this? With authority and power he gives orders to evil spirits, and they come out.”
4.37: So news about him spread to every place throughout the surrounding region.
4.38: Yeshua left the synagogue and went to Simon’s house. Simon’s mother-in-law was sick with a high fever. They asked Yeshua to help her.
4.39: He bent over her, ordered the fever to leave, and it went away. She got up immediately and prepared a meal for them.
4.40: When the sun was setting, everyone who had friends suffering from various diseases brought them to him. He placed his hands on each of them and cured them.
4.41: Demons came out of many people, shouting, “You are the Son of God!” But Yeshua ordered them not to speak. After all, they knew he was the Messiah.
4.42: In the morning he went to a place where he could be alone. The crowds searched for him. When they came to him, they tried to keep him from leaving.
4.43: But he said to them, “I have to tell the Good News about the kingdom of God in other cities also. That’s what I was sent to do.”
4.44: So he spread his message in the synagogues of Judea.

5.1: One day Yeshua was standing by the Sea of Galilee. The people crowded around him as they listened to God’s word.
5.2: Yeshua saw two boats on the shore. The fishermen had stepped out of them and were washing their nets.
5.3: So Yeshua got into the boat that belonged to Simon and asked him to push off a little from the shore. Then Yeshua sat down and taught the crowd from the boat.
5.4: When he finished speaking, he told Simon, “Take the boat into deep water, and lower your nets to catch some fish.”
5.5: Simon answered, “Teacher, we worked hard all night and caught nothing. But if you say so, I’ll lower the nets.”
5.6: After the men had done this, they caught such a large number of fish that their nets began to tear.
5.7: So they signaled to their partners in the other boat to come and help them. Their partners came and filled both boats until the boats nearly sank.
5.8: When Simon Peter saw this, he knelt in front of Yeshua and said, “Leave me, Lord! I’m a sinful person!”
5.9: Simon and everyone who was with him were amazed to see the large number of fish they had caught.
5.10:
James and John, who were Zebedee’s sons and Simon’s partners, were also amazed.
Yeshua told Simon, “Don’t be afraid. From now on you will catch people instead of fish.”
5.11: Simon and his partners brought the boats to shore, left everything, and followed Yeshua.
5.12: One day Yeshua was in a city where there was a man covered with a serious skin disease. When the man saw Yeshua, he bowed with his face to the ground. He begged Yeshua, “Sir, if you want to, you can make me clean.”
5.13: Yeshua reached out, touched him, and said, “I want to. So be clean!” Immediately, his skin disease went away.
5.14: Yeshua ordered him, “Don’t tell anyone. Instead, show yourself to the priest. Then offer the sacrifice as Moses commanded as proof to people that you are clean.”
5.15: The news about Yeshua spread even more. Large crowds gathered to hear him and have their diseases cured.
5.16: But he would go away to places where he could be alone for prayer.
5.17: One day when Yeshua was teaching, some Pharisees and experts in Moses’ Teachings were present. They had come from every village in Galilee and Judea and from Jerusalem. Yeshua had the power of the Lord to heal.
5.18: Some men brought a paralyzed man on a stretcher. They tried to take him into the house and put him in front of Yeshua.
5.19: But they could not find a way to get him into the house because of the crowd. So they went up on the roof. They made an opening in the tiles and let the man down on his stretcher among the people. (They lowered him in front of Yeshua.)
5.20: When Yeshua saw their faith, he said, “Sir, your sins are forgiven.”
5.21: The experts in Moses’ Teachings and the Pharisees thought, “Who is this man? He’s dishonoring God! Who besides God can forgive sins?”
5.22: Yeshua knew what they were thinking. So he said to them, “What are you thinking?
5.23: Is it easier to say, ‘Your sins are forgiven,’ or to say, ‘Get up and walk’?
5.24: I want you to know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins.” Then he said to the paralyzed man, “Get up, pick up your stretcher, and go home.”
5.25: The man immediately stood up in front of them and picked up the stretcher he had been lying on. Praising God, he went home.
5.26: Everyone was amazed and praised God. They were filled with awe and said, “We’ve seen things today we can hardly believe!”
5.27: After that, Yeshua left. He saw a tax collector named Levi sitting in a tax office. Yeshua said to him, “Follow me!”
5.28: So Levi got up, left everything, and followed him.
5.29: Levi held a large reception at his home for Yeshua. A huge crowd of tax collectors and others were eating with them.
5.30: The Pharisees and their experts in Moses’ Teachings complained to Yeshua’s disciples. They asked, “Why do you eat and drink with tax collectors and sinners?”
5.31: Yeshua answered them, “Healthy people don’t need a doctor; those who are sick do.
5.32: I’ve come to call sinners to change the way they think and act, not to call people who think they have God’s approval.”
5.33: They said to him, “John’s disciples frequently fast and say prayers, and so do the disciples of the Pharisees. But your disciples eat and drink.”
5.34: Yeshua asked them, “Can you force wedding guests to fast while the groom is still with them?
5.35: The time will come when the groom will be taken away from them. At that time they will fast.”
5.36: He also used these illustrations: “No one tears a piece of cloth from a new coat to patch an old coat. Otherwise, the new cloth will tear the old. Besides, the patch from the new will not match the old.
5.37: People don’t pour new wine into old wineskins. If they do, the new wine will make the skins burst. The wine will run out, and the skins will be ruined.
5.38: Rather, new wine is to be poured into fresh skins.
5.39: “No one who has been drinking old wine wants new wine. He says, ‘The old wine is better!’”

6.1: Once, on a day of worship, Yeshua was walking through some grainfields. His disciples were picking the heads of grain, removing the husks, and eating the grain.
6.2: Some of the Pharisees asked, “Why are your disciples doing something that is not right to do on the day of worship?”
6.3: Yeshua answered them, “Haven’t you read what David did when he and his men were hungry?
6.4: Haven’t you read how he went into the house of God, ate the bread of the presence, and gave some of it to the men who were with him? He had no right to eat those loaves. Only the priests have that right.”
6.5: Then he added, “The Son of Man has authority over the day of worship.”
6.6: On another day of worship, Yeshua went into a synagogue to teach. A man whose right hand was paralyzed was there.
6.7: The experts in Moses’ Teachings and the Pharisees were watching Yeshua closely. They wanted to see whether he would heal the man on the day of worship so that they could find a way to accuse him of doing something wrong.
6.8: But Yeshua knew what they were thinking. So he told the man with the paralyzed hand, “Get up, and stand in the center of the synagogue!” The man got up and stood there.
6.9: Then Yeshua said to them, “I ask you—what is the right thing to do on a day of worship: to do good or evil, to give a person his health or to destroy it?”
6.10: He looked around at all of them and then said to the man, “Hold out your hand.” The man did so, and his hand became normal again.
6.11: The experts in Moses’ Teachings and Pharisees were furious and began to discuss with each other what they could do to Yeshua.
6.12: At that time Yeshua went to a mountain to pray. He spent the whole night in prayer to God.
6.13: When it was day, he called his disciples. He chose twelve of them and called them apostles.
6.14: They were Simon (whom Yeshua named Peter) and Simon’s brother Andrew, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew,
6.15: Matthew, Thomas, James (son of Alphaeus), Simon (who was called the Zealot),
6.16: Judas (son of James), and Judas Iscariot (who became a traitor).
6.17: Yeshua came down from the mountain with them and stood on a level place. A large crowd of his disciples and many other people were there. They had come from all over Judea, Jerusalem, and the seacoast of Tyre and Sidon.
6.18: They wanted to hear him and be cured of their diseases. Those who were tormented by evil spirits were cured.
6.19: The entire crowd was trying to touch him because power was coming from him and curing all of them.
6.20:
Yeshua looked at his disciples and said,
“Blessed are those who are poor.
    The kingdom of God is theirs.
6.21:
Blessed are those who are hungry.
    They will be satisfied.
    Blessed are those who are crying.
    They will laugh.
6.22:
Blessed are you when people hate you, avoid you,
    insult you, and slander you
        because you are committed to the Son of Man.
6.23:
Rejoice then, and be very happy!
    You have a great reward in heaven.
        That’s the way their ancestors treated the prophets.
6.24:
“But how horrible it will be for those who are rich.
    They have had their comfort.
6.25:
How horrible it will be for those who are well-fed.
    They will be hungry.
    How horrible it will be for those who are laughing.
    They will mourn and cry.
6.26:
How horrible it will be for you
    when everyone says nice things about you.
        That’s the way their ancestors treated the false prophets.
6.27: “But I tell everyone who is listening: Love your enemies. Be kind to those who hate you.
6.28: Bless those who curse you. Pray for those who insult you.
6.29: If someone strikes you on the cheek, offer the other cheek as well. If someone takes your coat, don’t stop him from taking your shirt.
6.30: Give to everyone who asks you for something. If someone takes what is yours, don’t insist on getting it back.
6.31: “Do for other people everything you want them to do for you.
6.32: “If you love those who love you, do you deserve any thanks for that? Even sinners love those who love them.
6.33: If you help those who help you, do you deserve any thanks for that? Sinners do that too.
6.34: If you lend anything to those from whom you expect to get something back, do you deserve any thanks for that? Sinners also lend to sinners to get back what they lend.
6.35: Rather, love your enemies, help them, and lend to them without expecting to get anything back. Then you will have a great reward. You will be the children of the Most High God. After all, he is kind to unthankful and evil people.
6.36: Be merciful as your Father is merciful.
6.37: “Stop judging, and you will never be judged. Stop condemning, and you will never be condemned. Forgive, and you will be forgiven.
6.38: Give, and you will receive. A large quantity, pressed together, shaken down, and running over will be put into your pocket. The standards you use for others will be applied to you.”
6.39: Yeshua also gave them this illustration: “Can one blind person lead another? Won’t both fall into the same pit?
6.40: A student is no better than his teacher. But everyone who is well-trained will be like his teacher.
6.41: “Why do you see the piece of sawdust in another believer’s eye and not notice the wooden beam in your own eye?
6.42: How can you say to another believer, ‘Friend, let me take the piece of sawdust out of your eye,’ when you don’t see the beam in your own eye? You hypocrite! First remove the beam from your own eye. Then you will see clearly to remove the piece of sawdust from another believer’s eye.
6.43: “A good tree doesn’t produce rotten fruit, and a rotten tree doesn’t produce good fruit.
6.44: Each tree is known by its fruit. You don’t pick figs from thorny plants or grapes from a thornbush.
6.45: Good people do the good that is in them. But evil people do the evil that is in them. The things people say come from inside them.
6.46: “Why do you call me Lord but don’t do what I tell you?
6.47: “I will show you what everyone who comes to me, hears what I say, and obeys it is like.
6.48: He is like a person who dug down to bedrock to lay the foundation of his home. When a flood came, the floodwaters pushed against that house. But the house couldn’t be washed away because it had a good foundation.
6.49: The person who hears what I say but doesn’t obey it is like someone who built a house on the ground without any foundation. The floodwaters pushed against it, and that house quickly collapsed and was destroyed.”

7.1: When Yeshua had finished everything he wanted to say to the people, he went to Capernaum.
7.2: There a Roman army officer’s valuable slave was sick and near death.
7.3: The officer had heard about Yeshua and sent some Jewish leaders to him. They were to ask Yeshua to come and save the servant’s life.
7.4: They came to Yeshua and begged, “He deserves your help.
7.5: He loves our people and built our synagogue at his own expense.”
7.6: Yeshua went with them. He was not far from the house when the officer sent friends to tell Yeshua, “Sir, don’t bother. I don’t deserve to have you come into my house.
7.7: That’s why I didn’t come to you. But just give a command, and let my servant be cured.
7.8: As you know, I’m in a chain of command and have soldiers at my command. I tell one of them, ‘Go!’ and he goes, and another, ‘Come!’ and he comes. I tell my servant, ‘Do this!’ and he does it.”
7.9: Yeshua was amazed at the officer when he heard these words. He turned to the crowd following him and said, “I can guarantee that I haven’t found faith as great as this in Israel.”
7.10: When the men who had been sent returned to the house, they found the servant healthy again.
7.11: Soon afterward, Yeshua went to a city called Nain. His disciples and a large crowd went with him.
7.12: As he came near the entrance to the city, he met a funeral procession. The dead man was a widow’s only child. A large crowd from the city was with her.
7.13: When the Lord saw her, he felt sorry for her. He said to her, “Don’t cry.”
7.14: He went up to the open coffin, took hold of it, and the men who were carrying it stopped. He said, “Young man, I’m telling you to come back to life!”
7.15: The dead man sat up and began to talk, and Yeshua gave him back to his mother.
7.16: Everyone was struck with fear and praised God. They said, “A great prophet has appeared among us,” and “God has taken care of his people.”
7.17: This news about Yeshua spread throughout Judea and the surrounding region.
7.18: John’s disciples told him about all these things. Then John called two of his disciples
7.19: and sent them to ask the Lord, “Are you the one who is coming, or should we look for someone else?”
7.20: The men came to Yeshua and said, “John the Baptizer sent us to ask you, ‘Are you the one who is coming, or should we look for someone else?’”
7.21: At that time Yeshua was curing many people who had diseases, sicknesses, and evil spirits. Also, he was giving back sight to many who were blind.
7.22: Yeshua answered John’s disciples, “Go back, and tell John what you have seen and heard: Blind people see again, lame people are walking, those with skin diseases are made clean, deaf people hear again, dead people are brought back to life, and poor people hear the Good News.
7.23: Whoever doesn’t lose his faith in me is indeed blessed.”
7.24: When John’s messengers had left, Yeshua spoke to the crowds about John. “What did you go into the desert to see? Tall grass swaying in the wind?
7.25: Really, what did you go to see? A man dressed in fine clothes? Those who wear splendid clothes and live in luxury are in royal palaces.
7.26: Really, what did you go to see? A prophet? Let me tell you that he is far more than a prophet.
7.27:
John is the one about whom Scripture says,
‘I am sending my messenger ahead of you
    to prepare the way in front of you.’
7.28: I can guarantee that of all the people ever born, no one is greater than John. Yet, the least important person in the kingdom of God is greater than John.
7.29: “All the people, including tax collectors, heard John. They admitted that God was right by letting John baptize them.
7.30: But the Pharisees and the experts in Moses’ Teachings rejected God’s plan for them. They refused to be baptized.
7.31: “How can I describe the people who are living now? What are they like?
7.32:
They are like children who sit in the marketplace and shout to each other,
‘We played music for you,
    but you didn’t dance.
    We sang a funeral song,
    but you didn’t cry.’
7.33: John the Baptizer has come neither eating bread nor drinking wine, and you say, ‘There’s a demon in him!’
7.34: The Son of Man has come eating and drinking, and you say, ‘Look at him! He’s a glutton and a drunk, a friend of tax collectors and sinners!’
7.35: “Yet, wisdom is proved right by all its results.”
7.36: One of the Pharisees invited Yeshua to eat with him. Yeshua went to the Pharisee’s house and was eating at the table.
7.37: A woman who lived a sinful life in that city found out that Yeshua was eating at the Pharisee’s house. So she took a bottle of perfume
7.38: and knelt at his feet. She was crying and washed his feet with her tears. Then she dried his feet with her hair, kissed them over and over again, and poured the perfume on them.
7.39: The Pharisee who had invited Yeshua saw this and thought, “If this man really were a prophet, he would know what sort of woman is touching him. She’s a sinner.”
7.40:
Yeshua spoke up, “Simon, I have something to say to you.”
Simon replied, “Teacher, you’re free to speak.”
7.41: So Yeshua said, “Two men owed a moneylender some money. One owed him five hundred silver coins, and the other owed him fifty.
7.42: When they couldn’t pay it back, he was kind enough to cancel their debts. Now, who do you think will love him the most?”
7.43:
Simon answered, “I suppose the one who had the largest debt canceled.”
Yeshua said to him, “You’re right!”
7.44: Then, turning to the woman, he said to Simon, “You see this woman, don’t you? I came into your house. You didn’t wash my feet. But she has washed my feet with her tears and dried them with her hair.
7.45: You didn’t give me a kiss. But ever since I came in, she has not stopped kissing my feet.
7.46: You didn’t put any olive oil on my head. But she has poured perfume on my feet.
7.47: That’s why I’m telling you that her many sins have been forgiven. Her great love proves that. But whoever receives little forgiveness loves very little.”
7.48: Then Yeshua said to her, “Your sins have been forgiven.”
7.49: The other guests thought, “Who is this man who even forgives sins?”
7.50: Yeshua said to the woman, “Your faith has saved you. Go in peace!”

8.1: After this, Yeshua traveled from one city and village to another. He spread the Good News about God’s kingdom. The twelve apostles were with him.
8.2: Also, some women were with him. They had been cured from evil spirits and various illnesses. These women were Mary, also called Magdalene, from whom seven demons had gone out;
8.3: Joanna, whose husband Chusa was Herod’s administrator; Susanna; and many other women. They provided financial support for Yeshua and his disciples.
8.4: When a large crowd had gathered and people had come to Yeshua from every city, he used this story as an illustration:
8.5: “A farmer went to plant his seeds. Some seeds were planted along the road, were trampled, and were devoured by birds.
8.6: Others were planted on rocky soil. When the plants came up, they withered because they had no moisture.
8.7: Others were planted among thornbushes. The thornbushes grew up with them and choked them.
8.8:
Others were planted on good ground. When they came up, they produced a hundred times as much as was planted.”
After he had said this, he called out, “Let the person who has ears listen!”
8.9: His disciples asked him what this story meant.
8.10: Yeshua answered, “Knowledge about the mysteries of the kingdom of God has been given directly to you. But it is given to others in stories. When they look, they don’t see, and when they hear, they don’t understand.
8.11: “This is what the story illustrates: The seed is God’s word.
8.12: Some people are like seeds that were planted along the road. They hear the word, but then the devil comes. He takes the word away from them so that they don’t believe and become saved.
8.13: Some people are like seeds on rocky soil. They welcome the word with joy whenever they hear it, but they don’t develop any roots. They believe for a while, but when their faith is tested, they abandon it.
8.14: The seeds that were planted among thornbushes are people who hear the word, but as life goes on the worries, riches, and pleasures of life choke them. So they don’t produce anything good.
8.15: The seeds that were planted on good ground are people who also hear the word. But they keep it in their good and honest hearts and produce what is good despite what life may bring.
8.16: “No one lights a lamp and hides it under a bowl or puts it under a bed. Instead, everyone who lights a lamp puts it on a lamp stand so that those who come in will see the light.
8.17: There is nothing hidden that will not be revealed. There is nothing kept secret that will not come to light.
8.18: “So pay attention to how you listen! Those who understand these mysteries will be given more knowledge. However, some people don’t understand these mysteries. Even what they think they understand will be taken away from them.”
8.19: His mother and his brothers came to see him. But they couldn’t meet with him because of the crowd.
8.20: Someone told Yeshua, “Your mother and your brothers are standing outside. They want to see you.”
8.21: He answered them, “My mother and my brothers are those who hear and do what God’s word says.”
8.22: One day Yeshua and his disciples got into a boat. He said to them, “Let’s cross to the other side of the lake.” So they started out.
8.23:
As they were sailing along, Yeshua fell asleep.
A violent storm came across the lake. The boat was taking on water, and they were in danger.
8.24:
They went to him, woke him up, and said, “Master! Master! We’re going to die!”
Then he got up and ordered the wind and the waves to stop. The wind stopped, and the sea became calm.
8.25:
He asked them, “Where is your faith?”
Frightened and amazed, they asked each other, “Who is this man? He gives orders to the wind and the water, and they obey him!”
8.26: They landed in the region of the Gerasenes across from Galilee.
8.27: When Yeshua stepped out on the shore, a certain man from the city met him. The man was possessed by demons and had not worn clothes for a long time. He would not stay in a house but lived in the tombs.
8.28: When he saw Yeshua, he shouted, fell in front of him, and said in a loud voice, “Why are you bothering me, Yeshua, Son of the Most High God? I beg you not to torture me!”
8.29: Yeshua ordered the evil spirit to come out of the man. (The evil spirit had controlled the man for a long time. People had kept him under guard. He was chained hand and foot. But he would break the chains. Then the demon would force him to go into the desert.)
8.30:
Yeshua asked him, “What is your name?”
He answered, “Legion [Six Thousand].” (Many demons had entered him.)
8.31: The demons begged Yeshua not to order them to go into the bottomless pit.
8.32: A large herd of pigs was feeding on a mountainside. The demons begged Yeshua to let them enter those pigs. So he let them do this.
8.33: The demons came out of the man and went into the pigs. Then the herd rushed down the cliff into the lake and drowned.
8.34: When those who had taken care of the pigs saw what had happened, they ran away. They reported everything in the city and countryside.
8.35: The people went to see what had happened. They came to Yeshua and found the man from whom the demons had gone out. Dressed and in his right mind, he was sitting at Yeshua’s feet. The people were frightened.
8.36: Those who had seen this told the people how Yeshua had restored the demon-possessed man to health.
8.37:
Then all the people from the surrounding region of the Gerasenes asked Yeshua to leave because they were terrified.
Yeshua got into a boat and started back.
8.38:
The man from whom the demons had gone out begged him, “Let me go with you.”
But Yeshua sent the man away and told him,
8.39: “Go home to your family, and tell them how much God has done for you.” So the man left. He went through the whole city and told people how much Yeshua had done for him.
8.40: When Yeshua came back, a crowd welcomed him. Everyone was expecting him.
8.41: A man named Jairus, a synagogue leader, arrived and quickly bowed down in front of Yeshua. He begged Yeshua to come to his home.
8.42: His only daughter, who was about twelve years old, was dying. As Yeshua went, the people were crowding around him.
8.43: A woman who had been suffering from chronic bleeding for twelve years was in the crowd. No one could cure her.
8.44: She came up behind Yeshua, touched the edge of his clothes, and her bleeding stopped at once.
8.45:
Yeshua asked, “Who touched me?”
After everyone denied touching him, Peter said, “Teacher, the people are crowding you and pressing against you.”
8.46: Yeshua said, “Someone touched me. I know power has gone out of me.”
8.47: The woman saw that she couldn’t hide. Trembling, she quickly bowed in front of him. There, in front of all the people, she told why she touched him and how she was cured at once.
8.48: Yeshua told her, “Daughter, your faith has made you well. Go in peace!”
8.49: While Yeshua was still speaking to her, someone came from the synagogue leader’s home. He said, “Your daughter is dead. Don’t bother the teacher anymore.”
8.50: When Yeshua heard this, he told the synagogue leader, “Don’t be afraid! Just believe, and she will get well.”
8.51: Yeshua went into the house. He allowed no one to go with him except Peter, John, James, and the child’s parents.
8.52: Everyone was crying and showing how sad they were. Yeshua said, “Don’t cry! She’s not dead. She’s just sleeping.”
8.53: They laughed at him because they knew she was dead.
8.54: But Yeshua took her hand and called out, “Child, get up!”
8.55: She came back to life and got up at once. He ordered her parents to give her something to eat.
8.56: They were amazed. Yeshua ordered them not to tell anyone what had happened.

9.1: Yeshua called the twelve apostles together and gave them power and authority over every demon and power and authority to cure diseases.
9.2: He sent them to spread the message about the kingdom of God and to cure the sick.
9.3: He told them, “Don’t take anything along on the trip. Don’t take a walking stick, traveling bag, any food, money, or a change of clothes.
9.4: When you go into a home, stay there until you’re ready to leave.
9.5: If people don’t welcome you, leave that city, and shake its dust off your feet as a warning to them.”
9.6: The apostles went from village to village, told the Good News, and cured the sick everywhere.
9.7: Herod the ruler heard about everything that was happening. He didn’t know what to make of it. Some people were saying that John had come back to life.
9.8: Others said that Elijah had appeared, and still others said that one of the prophets from long ago had come back to life.
9.9: Herod said, “I had John’s head cut off. Who is this person I’m hearing so much about?” So Herod wanted to see Yeshua.
9.10: The apostles came back and told Yeshua everything they had done. He took them with him to a city called Bethsaida so that they could be alone.
9.11: But the crowds found out about this and followed him. He welcomed them, talked to them about the kingdom of God, and cured those who were sick.
9.12: Toward the end of the day, the twelve apostles came to him. They said to him, “Send the crowd to the closest villages and farms so that they can find some food and a place to stay. No one lives around here.”
9.13:
Yeshua replied, “You give them something to eat.”
They said to him, “We have five loaves of bread and two fish. Unless we go to buy food for all these people, that’s all we have.”
9.14:
(There were about five thousand men.)
Then he told his disciples, “Have them sit in groups of about fifty.”
9.16: Then he took the five loaves and the two fish, looked up to heaven, and blessed the food. He broke the loaves apart and kept giving them to the disciples to give to the crowd.
9.17: All of them ate as much as they wanted. When they picked up the leftover pieces, they filled twelve baskets.
9.18: Once when Yeshua was praying privately and his disciples were with him, he asked them, “Who do people say I am?”
9.19: They answered, “Some say you are John the Baptizer, others Elijah, and still others say that one of the prophets from long ago has come back to life.”
9.20:
He asked them, “But who do you say I am?”
Peter answered, “You are the Messiah, whom God has sent.”
9.21: He ordered them not to tell this to anyone.
9.22: Yeshua said that the Son of Man would have to suffer a lot. He would be rejected by the leaders, the chief priests, and the experts in Moses’ Teachings. He would be killed, but on the third day he would come back to life.
9.23: He said to all of them, “Those who want to come with me must say no to the things they want, pick up their crosses every day, and follow me.
9.24: Those who want to save their lives will lose them. But those who lose their lives for me will save them.
9.25: What good does it do for people to win the whole world but lose their lives by destroying them?
9.26: If people are ashamed of me and what I say, the Son of Man will be ashamed of those people when he comes in the glory that he shares with the Father and the holy angels.
9.27: “I can guarantee this truth: Some people who are standing here will not die until they see the kingdom of God.”
9.28: About eight days after he had said this, Yeshua took Peter, John, and James with him and went up a mountain to pray.
9.29: While Yeshua was praying, the appearance of his face changed, and his clothes became dazzling white.
9.30: Suddenly, both Moses and Elijah were talking with him.
9.31: They appeared in heavenly glory and were discussing Yeshua’s approaching death and what he was about to fulfill in Jerusalem.
9.32: Peter and the men with him were sleeping soundly. When they woke up, they saw Yeshua’s glory and the two men standing with him.
9.33: As Moses and Elijah were leaving him, Peter said to Yeshua, “Teacher, it’s good that we’re here. Let’s put up three tents—one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.” Peter didn’t know what he was saying.
9.34: While he was saying this, a cloud overshadowed them. They were frightened as they went into the cloud.
9.35: A voice came out of the cloud and said, “This is my Son, whom I have chosen. Listen to him!”
9.36: After the voice had spoken, they saw that Yeshua was alone. The disciples said nothing, and for some time they told no one about what they had seen.
9.37: The next day, when they had come down from the mountain, a large crowd met Yeshua.
9.38: A man in the crowd shouted, “Teacher, I beg you to look at my son. He’s my only child.
9.39: Whenever a spirit takes control of him, he shrieks, goes into convulsions, and foams at the mouth. After a struggle, the spirit goes away, leaving the child worn out.
9.40: I begged your disciples to force the spirit out of him, but they couldn’t do it.”
9.41: Yeshua answered, “You unbelieving and corrupt generation! How long must I be with you and put up with you? Bring your son here!”
9.42:
While he was coming to Yeshua, the demon knocked the boy to the ground and threw him into convulsions.
Yeshua ordered the evil spirit to leave. He cured the boy and gave him back to his father.
9.43:
Everyone was amazed to see God’s wonderful power.
Everyone was amazed at all the things that Yeshua was doing. So he said to his disciples,
9.44: “Listen carefully to what I say. The Son of Man will be betrayed and handed over to people.”
9.45: They didn’t know what he meant. The meaning was hidden from them so that they didn’t understand it. Besides, they were afraid to ask him about what he had said.
9.46: A discussion started among them about who would be the greatest.
9.47: Yeshua knew what they were thinking. So he took a little child and had him stand beside him.
9.48: Then he said to them, “Whoever welcomes this little child in my name welcomes me. Whoever welcomes me welcomes the one who sent me. The one who is least among all of you is the one who is greatest.”
9.49: John replied, “Master, we saw someone forcing demons out of a person by using the power and authority of your name. We tried to stop him because he was not one of us.”
9.50: Yeshua said to him, “Don’t stop him! Whoever isn’t against you is for you.”
9.51: The time was coming closer for Yeshua to be taken to heaven. So he was determined to go to Jerusalem.
9.52: He sent messengers ahead of him. They went into a Samaritan village to arrange a place for him to stay.
9.53: But the people didn’t welcome him, because he was on his way to Jerusalem.
9.54: James and John, his disciples, saw this. They asked, “Lord, do you want us to call down fire from heaven to burn them up?”
9.55: But he turned and corrected them.
9.56: So they went to another village.
9.57: As they were walking along the road, a man said to Yeshua, “I’ll follow you wherever you go.”
9.58: Yeshua told him, “Foxes have holes, and birds have nests, but the Son of Man has nowhere to sleep.”
9.59:
He told another man, “Follow me!”
But the man said, “Sir, first let me go to bury my father.”
9.60: But Yeshua told him, “Let the dead bury their own dead. You must go everywhere and tell about the kingdom of God.”
9.61: Another said, “I’ll follow you, sir, but first let me tell my family goodbye.”
9.62: Yeshua said to him, “Whoever starts to plow and looks back is not fit for the kingdom of God.”

10.1: After this, the Lord appointed 70 other disciples to go ahead of him to every city and place that he intended to go. They were to travel in pairs.
10.2: He told them, “The harvest is large, but the workers are few. So ask the Lord who gives this harvest to send workers to harvest his crops.
10.3: Go! I’m sending you out like lambs among wolves.
10.4: Don’t carry a wallet, a traveling bag, or sandals, and don’t stop to greet anyone on the way.
10.5: Whenever you go into a house, greet the family right away with the words, ‘May there be peace in this house.’
10.6: If a peaceful person lives there, your greeting will be accepted. But if that’s not the case, your greeting will be rejected.
10.7: Stay with the family that accepts you. Eat and drink whatever they offer you. After all, the worker deserves his pay. Do not move around from one house to another.
10.8: Whenever you go into a city and the people welcome you, eat whatever they serve you.
10.9: Heal the sick that are there, and tell the people, ‘The kingdom of God is near you!’
10.10: “But whenever you go into a city and people don’t welcome you, leave. Announce in its streets,
10.11: ‘We are wiping your city’s dust from our feet in protest against you! But realize that the kingdom of God is near you!’
10.12: I can guarantee that judgment day will be easier for Sodom than for that city.
10.13: “How horrible it will be for you, Chorazin! How horrible it will be for you, Bethsaida! If the miracles worked in your cities had been worked in Tyre and Sidon, they would have changed the way they thought and acted. Long ago they would have worn sackcloth and sat in ashes.
10.14: Judgment day will be better for Tyre and Sidon than for you.
10.15: And you, Capernaum, will you be lifted to heaven? No, you will go to hell!
10.16: “The person who hears you hears me, and the person who rejects you rejects me. The person who rejects me rejects the one who sent me.”
10.17: The 70 disciples came back very happy. They said, “Lord, even demons obey us when we use the power and authority of your name!”
10.18: Yeshua said to them, “I watched Satan fall from heaven like lightning.
10.19: I have given you the authority to trample snakes and scorpions and to destroy the enemy’s power. Nothing will hurt you.
10.20: However, don’t be happy that evil spirits obey you. Be happy that your names are written in heaven.”
10.21: In that hour the Holy Spirit filled Yeshua with joy. Yeshua said, “I praise you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, for hiding these things from wise and intelligent people and revealing them to little children. Yes, Father, this is what pleased you.
10.22: “My Father has turned everything over to me. Only the Father knows who the Son is. And no one knows who the Father is except the Son and those to whom the Son is willing to reveal him.”
10.23: He turned to his disciples in private and said to them, “How blessed you are to see what you’ve seen.
10.24: I can guarantee that many prophets and kings wanted to see and hear what you’ve seen and heard, but they didn’t.”
10.25: Then an expert in Moses’ Teachings stood up to test Yeshua. He asked, “Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?”
10.26: Yeshua answered him, “What is written in Moses’ Teachings? What do you read there?”
10.27: He answered, “‘Love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, with all your strength, and with all your mind. And love your neighbor as you love yourself.’”
10.28: Yeshua told him, “You’re right! Do this, and life will be yours.”
10.29: But the man wanted to justify his question. So he asked Yeshua, “Who is my neighbor?”
10.30: Yeshua replied, “A man went from Jerusalem to Jericho. On the way robbers stripped him, beat him, and left him for dead.
10.31: “By chance, a priest was traveling along that road. When he saw the man, he went around him and continued on his way.
10.32: Then a Levite came to that place. When he saw the man, he, too, went around him and continued on his way.
10.33: “But a Samaritan, as he was traveling along, came across the man. When the Samaritan saw him, he felt sorry for the man,
10.34: went to him, and cleaned and bandaged his wounds. Then he put him on his own animal, brought him to an inn, and took care of him.
10.35: The next day the Samaritan took out two silver coins and gave them to the innkeeper. He told the innkeeper, ‘Take care of him. If you spend more than that, I’ll pay you on my return trip.’
10.36: “Of these three men, who do you think was a neighbor to the man who was attacked by robbers?”
10.37:
The expert said, “The one who was kind enough to help him.”
Yeshua told him, “Go and imitate his example!”
10.38: As they were traveling along, Yeshua went into a village. A woman named Martha welcomed him into her home.
10.39: She had a sister named Mary. Mary sat at the Lord’s feet and listened to him talk.
10.40: But Martha was upset about all the work she had to do. So she asked, “Lord, don’t you care that my sister has left me to do the work all by myself? Tell her to help me.”
10.41: The Lord answered her, “Martha, Martha! You worry and fuss about a lot of things.
10.42: There’s only one thing you need. Mary has made the right choice, and that one thing will not be taken away from her.”

11.1: Once Yeshua was praying in a certain place. When he stopped praying, one of his disciples said to him, “Lord, teach us to pray as John taught his disciples.”
11.2:
Yeshua told them, “When you pray, say this:
Father,
    let your name be kept holy.
    Let your kingdom come.
11.3: Give us our bread day by day.
11.4:
Forgive us as we forgive everyone else.
    Don’t allow us to be tempted.”
11.5: Yeshua said to his disciples, “Suppose one of you has a friend. Suppose you go to him at midnight and say, ‘Friend, let me borrow three loaves of bread.
11.6: A friend of mine on a trip has dropped in on me, and I don’t have anything to serve him.’
11.7: Your friend might answer you from inside his house, ‘Don’t bother me! The door is already locked, and my children are in bed. I can’t get up to give you anything.’
11.8: I can guarantee that although he doesn’t want to get up to give you anything, he will get up and give you whatever you need because he is your friend and because you were so bold.
11.9: “So I tell you to ask, and you will receive. Search, and you will find. Knock, and the door will be opened for you.
11.10: Everyone who asks will receive. The one who searches will find, and for the person who knocks, the door will be opened.
11.11: “If your child asks you, his father, for a fish, would you give him a snake instead?
11.12: Or if your child asks you for an egg, would you give him a scorpion?
11.13: Even though you’re evil, you know how to give good gifts to your children. So how much more will your Father in heaven give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him?”
11.14:
Yeshua was forcing a demon out of a man. The demon had made the man unable to talk. When the demon had gone out, the man began to talk.
The people were amazed.
11.15: But some of them said, “He can force demons out of people only with the help of Beelzebul, the ruler of demons.”
11.16: Others wanted to test Yeshua and demanded that he show them some miraculous sign from heaven.
11.17: Since Yeshua knew what they were thinking, he said to them, “Every kingdom divided against itself is ruined. A house divided against itself falls.
11.18: Now, if Satan is divided against himself, how can his kingdom last? I say this because you say Beelzebul helps me force demons out of people.
11.19: If I force demons out with the help of Beelzebul, who helps your followers force them out? That’s why they will be your judges.
11.20: But if I force out demons with the help of God’s power, then the kingdom of God has come to you.
11.21: “When a strong man, fully armed, guards his own mansion, his property is safe.
11.22: But a stronger man than he may attack him and defeat him. Then the stronger man will take away all the weapons in which the strong man trusted and will divide the loot.
11.23: “Whoever isn’t with me is against me. Whoever doesn’t gather with me scatters.
11.24: “When an evil spirit comes out of a person, it goes through dry places looking for a place to rest. But it doesn’t find any. Then it says, ‘I’ll go back to the home I left.’
11.25: When it comes, it finds the house swept clean and in order.
11.26: Then the spirit goes and brings along seven other spirits more evil than itself. They enter and take up permanent residence there. In the end the condition of that person is worse than it was before.”
11.27: While Yeshua was speaking, a woman in the crowd shouted, “How blessed is the mother who gave birth to you and the breasts that nursed you.”
11.28: Yeshua replied, “Rather, how blessed are those who hear and obey God’s word.”
11.29: As the people were gathering around him, Yeshua said, “The people living today are evil. They look for a miraculous sign. But the only sign they will get is the sign of Jonah.
11.30: Just as Jonah became a miraculous sign to the people of Nineveh, so the Son of Man will be a miraculous sign to the people living today.
11.31: The queen from the south will stand up at the time of judgment with the men who live today. She will condemn them, because she came from the ends of the earth to hear Solomon’s wisdom. But look, someone greater than Solomon is here!
11.32: The men of Nineveh will stand up at the time of judgment with the people living today. Since the men of Nineveh turned to God and changed the way they thought and acted when Jonah spoke his message, they will condemn the people living today. But look, someone greater than Jonah is here!
11.33: “No one lights a lamp and hides it or puts it under a basket. Instead, everyone who lights a lamp puts it on a lamp stand so that those who come in will see its light.
11.34: “Your eye is the lamp of your body. When your eye is unclouded, your whole body is full of light. But when your eye is evil, your body is full of darkness.
11.35: So be careful that the light in you isn’t darkness.
11.36: If your whole body is full of light and not darkness, it will be as bright as a lamp shining on you.”
11.37: After Yeshua spoke, a Pharisee invited him to have lunch at his house. So Yeshua accepted the invitation.
11.38: The Pharisee was surprised to see that Yeshua didn’t wash before the meal.
11.39: The Lord said to him, “You Pharisees clean the outside of cups and dishes. But inside you are full of greed and evil.
11.40: You fools! Didn’t the one who made the outside make the inside too?
11.41: Give what is inside as a gift to the poor, and then everything will be clean for you.
11.42: “How horrible it will be for you Pharisees! You give God one-tenth of your mint, spices, and every garden herb. But you have ignored justice and the love of God. You should have done these things without ignoring the others.
11.43: “How horrible it will be for you Pharisees! You love to sit in the front seats in the synagogues and to be greeted in the marketplaces.
11.44: How horrible it will be for you! You are like unmarked graves. People walk on them without knowing what they are.”
11.45: One of the experts in Moses’ Teachings said to him, “Teacher, when you talk this way, you insult us too.”
11.46: Yeshua said, “How horrible it will be for you experts in Moses’ Teachings! You burden people with loads that are hard to carry. But you won’t lift a finger to carry any of these loads.
11.47: “How horrible it will be for you! You build the monuments for the prophets. But it was your ancestors who murdered them.
11.48: So you are witnesses and approve of what your ancestors did. They murdered the prophets for whom you build monuments.
11.49: That’s why the Wisdom of God said, ‘I will send them prophets and apostles. They will murder some of those prophets and apostles and persecute others.’
11.50: So the people living now will be charged with the murder of every prophet since the world was made.
11.51: This includes the murders from Abel to Zechariah, who was killed between the altar and the temple. Yes, I can guarantee this truth: The people living today will be held responsible for this.
11.52: “How horrible it will be for you experts in Moses’ Teachings! You have taken away the key that unlocks knowledge. You haven’t gained entrance into knowledge yourselves, and you’ve kept out those who wanted to enter.”
11.53: When Yeshua left, the experts in Moses’ Teachings and the Pharisees held a terrible grudge against him. They questioned him about many things
11.54: and watched him closely to trap him in something he might say.

12.1: Meanwhile, thousands of people had gathered. They were so crowded that they stepped on each other. Yeshua spoke to his disciples and said, “Watch out for the yeast of the Pharisees. I’m talking about their hypocrisy.
12.2: Nothing has been covered that will not be exposed. Whatever is secret will be made known.
12.3: Whatever you have said in the dark will be heard in the daylight. Whatever you have whispered in private rooms will be shouted from the housetops.
12.4: “My friends, I can guarantee that you don’t need to be afraid of those who kill the body. After that they can’t do anything more.
12.5: I’ll show you the one you should be afraid of. Be afraid of the one who has the power to throw you into hell after killing you. I’m warning you to be afraid of him.
12.6: “Aren’t five sparrows sold for two cents? God doesn’t forget any of them.
12.7: Even every hair on your head has been counted. Don’t be afraid! You are worth more than many sparrows.
12.8: I can guarantee that the Son of Man will acknowledge in front of God’s angels every person who acknowledges him in front of others.
12.9: But God’s angels will be told that I don’t know those people who tell others that they don’t know me.
12.10: Everyone who says something against the Son of Man will be forgiven. But the person who dishonors the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven.
12.11: “When you are put on trial in synagogues or in front of rulers and authorities, don’t worry about how you will defend yourselves or what you will say.
12.12: At that time the Holy Spirit will teach you what you must say.”
12.13: Someone in the crowd said to him, “Teacher, tell my brother to give me my share of the inheritance that our father left us.”
12.14: Yeshua said to him, “Who appointed me to be your judge or to divide your inheritance?”
12.15: He told the people, “Be careful to guard yourselves from every kind of greed. Life is not about having a lot of material possessions.”
12.16: Then he used this illustration. He said, “A rich man had land that produced good crops.
12.17: He thought, ‘What should I do? I don’t have enough room to store my crops.’
12.18: He said, ‘I know what I’ll do. I’ll tear down my barns and build bigger ones so that I can store all my grain and goods in them.
12.19: Then I’ll say to myself, “You’ve stored up a lot of good things for years to come. Take life easy, eat, drink, and enjoy yourself.” ’
12.20: “But God said to him, ‘You fool! I will demand your life from you tonight! Now who will get what you’ve accumulated?’
12.21: That’s how it is when a person has material riches but is not rich in his relationship with God.”
12.22: Then Yeshua said to his disciples, “So I tell you to stop worrying about what you will eat or wear.
12.23: Life is more than food, and the body is more than clothes.
12.24: Consider the crows. They don’t plant or harvest. They don’t even have a storeroom or a barn. Yet, God feeds them. You are worth much more than birds.
12.25: “Can any of you add an hour to your life by worrying?
12.26: If you can’t do a small thing like that, why worry about other things?
12.27: Consider how the flowers grow. They never work or spin yarn for clothes. But I say that not even Solomon in all his majesty was dressed like one of these flowers.
12.28: That’s the way God clothes the grass in the field. Today it’s alive, and tomorrow it’s thrown into an incinerator. So how much more will he clothe you people who have so little faith?
12.29: “Don’t concern yourself about what you will eat or drink, and quit worrying about these things.
12.30: Everyone in the world is concerned about these things, but your Father knows you need them.
12.31: Rather, be concerned about his kingdom. Then these things will be provided for you.
12.32: Don’t be afraid, little flock. Your Father is pleased to give you the kingdom.
12.33: “Sell your material possessions, and give the money to the poor. Make yourselves wallets that don’t wear out! Make a treasure for yourselves in heaven that never loses its value! In heaven thieves and moths can’t get close enough to destroy your treasure.
12.34: Your heart will be where your treasure is.
12.35: “Be ready for action, and have your lamps burning.
12.36: Be like servants waiting to open the door at their master’s knock when he returns from a wedding.
12.37: Blessed are those servants whom the master finds awake when he comes. I can guarantee this truth: He will change his clothes, make them sit down at the table, and serve them.
12.38: They will be blessed if he comes in the middle of the night or toward morning and finds them awake.
12.39: “Of course, you realize that if the homeowner had known at what hour the thief was coming, he would not have let him break into his house.
12.40: Be ready, because the Son of Man will return when you least expect him.”
12.41: Peter asked, “Lord, did you use this illustration just for us or for everyone?”
12.42: The Lord asked, “Who, then, is the faithful, skilled manager that the master will put in charge of giving the other servants their share of food at the right time?
12.43: That servant will be blessed if his master finds him doing this job when he comes.
12.44: I can guarantee this truth: He will put that servant in charge of all his property.
12.45: On the other hand, that servant may think that his master is taking a long time to come home. The servant may begin to beat the other servants and to eat, drink, and get drunk.
12.46: His master will return at an unexpected time. Then his master will punish him severely and assign him a place with unfaithful people.
12.47: “The servant who knew what his master wanted but didn’t get ready to do it will receive a hard beating.
12.48: But the servant who didn’t know what his master wanted and did things for which he deserved punishment will receive a light beating. A lot will be expected from everyone who has been given a lot. More will be demanded from everyone who has been entrusted with a lot.
12.49: “I have come to throw fire on the earth. I wish that it had already started!
12.50: I have a baptism to go through, and I will suffer until it is over.
12.51: “Do you think I came to bring peace to earth? No! I can guarantee that I came to bring nothing but division.
12.52: From now on a family of five will be divided. Three will be divided against two and two against three.
12.53: A father will be against his son and a son against his father. A mother will be against her daughter and a daughter against her mother. A mother-in-law will be against her daughter-in-law and a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law.”
12.54: Yeshua said to the crowds, “When you see a cloud coming up in the west, you immediately say, ‘There’s going to be a rainstorm,’ and it happens.
12.55: When you see a south wind blowing, you say, ‘It’s going to be hot,’ and that’s what happens.
12.56: You hypocrites! You can forecast the weather by judging the appearance of earth and sky. But for some reason you don’t know how to judge the time in which you’re living.
12.57: So why don’t you judge for yourselves what is right?
12.58: For instance, when an opponent brings you to court in front of a ruler, do your best to settle with him before you get there. Otherwise, he will drag you in front of a judge. The judge will hand you over to an officer who will throw you into prison.
12.59: I can guarantee that you won’t get out until you pay every penny of your fine.”

13.1: At that time some people reported to Yeshua about some Galileans whom Pilate had executed while they were sacrificing animals.
13.2: Yeshua replied to them, “Do you think that this happened to them because they were more sinful than other people from Galilee?
13.3: No! I can guarantee that they weren’t. But if you don’t turn to God and change the way you think and act, then you, too, will all die.
13.4: What about those 18 people who died when the tower at Siloam fell on them? Do you think that they were more sinful than other people living in Jerusalem?
13.5: No! I can guarantee that they weren’t. But if you don’t turn to God and change the way you think and act, then you, too, will all die.”
13.6: Then Yeshua used this illustration: “A man had a fig tree growing in his vineyard. He went to look for fruit on the tree but didn’t find any.
13.7: He said to the gardener, ‘For the last three years I’ve come to look for figs on this fig tree but haven’t found any. Cut it down! Why should it use up good soil?’
13.8: “The gardener replied, ‘Sir, let it stand for one more year. I’ll dig around it and fertilize it.
13.9: Maybe next year it’ll have figs. But if not, then cut it down.’”
13.10: Yeshua was teaching in a synagogue on the day of worship.
13.11: A woman who was possessed by a spirit was there. The spirit had disabled her for 18 years. She was hunched over and couldn’t stand up straight.
13.12: When Yeshua saw her, he called her to come to him and said, “Woman, you are free from your disability.”
13.13: He placed his hands on her, and she immediately stood up straight and praised God.
13.14: The synagogue leader was irritated with Yeshua for healing on the day of worship. The leader told the crowd, “There are six days when work can be done. So come on one of those days to be healed. Don’t come on the day of worship.”
13.15: The Lord said, “You hypocrites! Don’t each of you free your ox or donkey on the day of worship? Don’t you then take it out of its stall to give it some water to drink?
13.16: Now, here is a descendant of Abraham. Satan has kept her in this condition for 18 years. Isn’t it right to free her on the day of worship?”
13.17: As he said this, everyone who opposed him felt ashamed. But the entire crowd was happy about the miraculous things he was doing.
13.18: Yeshua asked, “What is the kingdom of God like? What can I compare it to?
13.19: It’s like a mustard seed that someone planted in a garden. It grew and became a tree, and the birds nested in its branches.”
13.20: He asked again, “What can I compare the kingdom of God to?
13.21: It’s like yeast that a woman mixed into a large amount of flour until the yeast worked its way through all the dough.”
13.22: Then Yeshua traveled and taught in one city and village after another on his way to Jerusalem.
13.23:
Someone asked him, “Sir, are only a few people going to be saved?”
He answered,
13.24: “Try hard to enter through the narrow door. I can guarantee that many will try to enter, but they won’t succeed.
13.25: After the homeowner gets up and closes the door, it’s too late. You can stand outside, knock at the door, and say, ‘Sir, open the door for us!’ But he will answer you, ‘I don’t know who you are.’
13.26: Then you will say, ‘We ate and drank with you, and you taught in our streets.’
13.27: But he will tell you, ‘I don’t know who you are. Get away from me, all you evil people.’
13.28: Then you will cry and be in extreme pain. That’s what you’ll do when you see Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and all the prophets. They’ll be in the kingdom of God, but you’ll be thrown out.
13.29: People will come from all over the world and will eat in the kingdom of God.
