13.30: Some who are last will be first, and some who are first will be last.”
13.31: At that time some Pharisees told Yeshua, “Get out of here, and go somewhere else! Herod wants to kill you.”
13.32: Yeshua said to them, “Tell that fox that I will force demons out of people and heal people today and tomorrow. I will finish my work on the third day.
13.33: But I must be on my way today, tomorrow, and the next day. It’s not possible for a prophet to die outside Jerusalem.
13.34: “Jerusalem, Jerusalem, you kill the prophets and stone to death those sent to you! How often I wanted to gather your children together the way a hen gathers her chicks under her wings! But you were not willing!
13.35: Your house will be abandoned. I can guarantee that you will not see me again until you say, ‘Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord!’”

14.1: On a day of worship Yeshua went to eat at the home of a prominent Pharisee. The guests were watching Yeshua very closely.
14.2: A man whose body was swollen with fluid was there.
14.3: Yeshua reacted by asking the Pharisees and the experts in Moses’ Teachings, “Is it right to heal on the day of worship or not?”
14.4:
But they didn’t say a thing.
So Yeshua took hold of the man, healed him, and sent him away.
14.5: Yeshua asked them, “If your son or your ox falls into a well on a day of worship, wouldn’t you pull him out immediately?”
14.6: They couldn’t argue with him about this.
14.7: Then Yeshua noticed how the guests always chose the places of honor. So he used this illustration when he spoke to them:
14.8: “When someone invites you to a wedding, don’t take the place of honor. Maybe someone more important than you was invited.
14.9: Then your host would say to you, ‘Give this person your place.’ Embarrassed, you would have to take the place of least honor.
14.10: So when you’re invited, take the place of least honor. Then, when your host comes, he will tell you, ‘Friend, move to a more honorable place.’ Then all the other guests will see how you are honored.
14.11: Those who honor themselves will be humbled, but people who humble themselves will be honored.”
14.12: Then he told the man who had invited him, “When you invite people for lunch or dinner, don’t invite only your friends, family, other relatives, or rich neighbors. Otherwise, they will return the favor.
14.13: Instead, when you give a banquet, invite the poor, the handicapped, the lame, and the blind.
14.14: Then you will be blessed because they don’t have any way to pay you back. You will be paid back when those who have God’s approval come back to life.”
14.15: One of those eating with him heard this. So he said to Yeshua, “The person who will be at the banquet in the kingdom of God is blessed.”
14.16: Yeshua said to him, “A man gave a large banquet and invited many people.
14.17: When it was time for the banquet, he sent his servant to tell those who were invited, ‘Come! Everything is ready now.’
14.18: “Everyone asked to be excused. The first said to him, ‘I bought a field, and I need to see it. Please excuse me.’
14.19: Another said, ‘I bought five pairs of oxen, and I’m on my way to see how well they plow. Please excuse me.’
14.20: Still another said, ‘I recently got married, and that’s why I can’t come.’
14.21: “The servant went back to report this to his master. Then the master of the house became angry. He told his servant, ‘Run to every street and alley in the city! Bring back the poor, the handicapped, the blind, and the lame.’
14.22: “The servant said, ‘Sir, what you’ve ordered has been done. But there is still room for more people.’
14.23: “Then the master told his servant, ‘Go to the roads and paths! Urge the people to come to my house. I want it to be full.
14.24: I can guarantee that none of those invited earlier will taste any food at my banquet.’”
14.25: Large crowds were traveling with Yeshua. He turned to them and said,
14.26: “If people come to me and are not ready to abandon their fathers, mothers, wives, children, brothers, and sisters, as well as their own lives, they cannot be my disciples.
14.27: So those who do not carry their crosses and follow me cannot be my disciples.
14.28: “Suppose you want to build a tower. You would first sit down and figure out what it costs. Then you would see if you have enough money to finish it.
14.29: Otherwise, if you lay a foundation and can’t finish the building, everyone who watches will make fun of you.
14.30: They’ll say, ‘This person started to build but couldn’t finish the job.’
14.31: “Or suppose a king is going to war against another king. He would first sit down and think things through. Can he and his 10,000 soldiers fight against a king with 20,000 soldiers?
14.32: If he can’t, he’ll send ambassadors to ask for terms of peace while the other king is still far away.
14.33: In the same way, none of you can be my disciples unless you give up everything.
14.34: “Salt is good. But if salt loses its taste, how will you restore its flavor?
14.35:
It’s not any good for the ground or for the manure pile. People throw it away.
“Let the person who has ears listen!”

15.1: All the tax collectors and sinners came to listen to Yeshua.
15.2: But the Pharisees and the experts in Moses’ Teachings complained, “This man welcomes sinners and eats with them.”
15.3: Yeshua spoke to them using this illustration:
15.4: “Suppose a man has 100 sheep and loses one of them. Doesn’t he leave the 99 sheep grazing in the pasture and look for the lost sheep until he finds it?
15.5: When he finds it, he’s happy. He puts that sheep on his shoulders and
15.6: goes home. Then he calls his friends and neighbors together and says to them, ‘Let’s celebrate! I’ve found my lost sheep!’
15.7: I can guarantee that there will be more happiness in heaven over one person who turns to God and changes the way he thinks and acts than over 99 people who already have turned to God and have his approval.”
15.8: “Suppose a woman has ten coins and loses one. Doesn’t she light a lamp, sweep the house, and look for the coin carefully until she finds it?
15.9: When she finds it, she calls her friends and neighbors together and says, ‘Let’s celebrate! I’ve found the coin that I lost.’
15.10: So I can guarantee that God’s angels are happy about one person who turns to God and changes the way he thinks and acts.”
15.11: Then Yeshua said, “A man had two sons.
15.12: The younger son said to his father, ‘Father, give me my share of the property.’ So the father divided his property between his two sons.
15.13: “After a few days, the younger son gathered his possessions and left for a country far away from home. There he wasted everything he had on a wild lifestyle.
15.14: He had nothing left when a severe famine spread throughout that country. He had nothing to live on.
15.15: So he got a job from someone in that country and was sent to feed pigs in the fields.
15.16: No one in the country would give him any food, and he was so hungry that he would have eaten what the pigs were eating.
15.17: “Finally, he came to his senses. He said, ‘How many of my father’s hired men have more food than they can eat, while I’m starving to death here?
15.18: I’ll go at once to my father, and I’ll say to him, “Father, I’ve sinned against heaven and you.
15.19: I don’t deserve to be called your son anymore. Make me one of your hired men.” ’
15.20: “So he went at once to his father. While he was still at a distance, his father saw him and felt sorry for him. He ran to his son, put his arms around him, and kissed him.
15.21: Then his son said to him, ‘Father, I’ve sinned against heaven and you. I don’t deserve to be called your son anymore.’
15.22: “The father said to his servants, ‘Hurry! Bring out the best robe, and put it on him. Put a ring on his finger and sandals on his feet.
15.23: Bring the fattened calf, kill it, and let’s celebrate with a feast.
15.24: My son was dead and has come back to life. He was lost but has been found.’ Then they began to celebrate.
15.25: “His older son was in the field. As he was coming back to the house, he heard music and dancing.
15.26: He called to one of the servants and asked what was happening.
15.27: “The servant told him, ‘Your brother has come home. So your father has killed the fattened calf to celebrate your brother’s safe return.’
15.28: “Then the older son became angry and wouldn’t go into the house. His father came out and begged him to come in.
15.29: But he answered his father, ‘All these years I’ve worked like a slave for you. I’ve never disobeyed one of your commands. Yet, you’ve never given me so much as a little goat for a celebration with my friends.
15.30: But this son of yours spent your money on prostitutes, and when he came home, you killed the fattened calf for him.’
15.31: “His father said to him, ‘My child, you’re always with me. Everything I have is yours.
15.32: But we have something to celebrate, something to be happy about. This brother of yours was dead but has come back to life. He was lost but has been found.’”

16.1: Then Yeshua said to his disciples, “A rich man had a business manager. The manager was accused of wasting the rich man’s property.
16.2: So the rich man called for his manager and said to him, ‘What’s this I hear about you? Let me examine your books. It’s obvious that you can’t manage my property any longer.’
16.3: “The manager thought, ‘What should I do? My master is taking my job away from me. I’m not strong enough to dig, and I’m ashamed to beg.
16.4: I know what I’ll do so that people will welcome me into their homes when I’ve lost my job.’
16.5: “So the manager called for each one of his master’s debtors. He said to the first, ‘How much do you owe my master?’
16.6:
“The debtor replied, ‘Eight hundred gallons of olive oil.’
“The manager told him, ‘Take my master’s ledger. Quick! Sit down, and write “four hundred!” ’
16.7:
“Then he asked another debtor, ‘How much do you owe?’
“The debtor replied, ‘A thousand bushels of wheat.’
“The manager told him, ‘Take the ledger, and write “eight hundred!” ’
16.8: “The master praised the dishonest manager for being so clever. Worldly people are more clever than spiritually-minded people when it comes to dealing with others.”
16.9: Yeshua continued, “I’m telling you that although wealth is often used in dishonest ways, you should use it to make friends for yourselves. When life is over, you will be welcomed into an eternal home.
16.10: Whoever can be trusted with very little can also be trusted with a lot. Whoever is dishonest with very little is dishonest with a lot.
16.11: Therefore, if you can’t be trusted with wealth that is often used dishonestly, who will trust you with wealth that is real?
16.12: If you can’t be trusted with someone else’s wealth, who will give you your own?
16.13: “A servant cannot serve two masters. He will hate the first master and love the second, or he will be devoted to the first and despise the second. You cannot serve God and wealth.”
16.14: The Pharisees, who love money, heard all this and were making sarcastic remarks about him.
16.15: So Yeshua said to them, “You try to justify your actions in front of people. But God knows what’s in your hearts. What is important to humans is disgusting to God.
16.16: “Moses’ Teachings and the Prophets were in force until the time of John. Since that time, people have been telling the Good News about the kingdom of God, and everyone is trying to force their way into it.
16.17: It is easier for the earth and the heavens to disappear than to drop a comma from the Scriptures.
16.18: “Any man who divorces his wife to marry another woman is committing adultery. The man who marries a woman divorced in this way is committing adultery.
16.19: “There was a rich man who wore expensive clothes. Every day was like a party to him.
16.20: There was also a beggar named Lazarus who was regularly brought to the gate of the rich man’s house.
16.21: Lazarus would have eaten any scraps that fell from the rich man’s table. Lazarus was covered with sores, and dogs would lick them.
16.22: “One day the beggar died, and the angels carried him to be with Abraham. The rich man also died and was buried.
16.23: He went to hell, where he was constantly tortured. As he looked up, in the distance he saw Abraham and Lazarus.
16.24: He yelled, ‘Father Abraham! Have mercy on me! Send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water to cool off my tongue. I am suffering in this fire.’
16.25: “Abraham replied, ‘Remember, my child, that you had a life filled with good times, while Lazarus’ life was filled with misery. Now he has peace here, while you suffer.
16.26: Besides, a wide area separates us. People couldn’t cross it in either direction even if they wanted to.’
16.27: “The rich man responded, ‘Then I ask you, Father, to send Lazarus back to my father’s home.
16.28: I have five brothers. He can warn them so that they won’t end up in this place of torture.’
16.29: “Abraham replied, ‘They have Moses’ Teachings and the Prophets. Your brothers should listen to them!’
16.30: “The rich man replied, ‘No, Father Abraham! If someone comes back to them from the dead, they will turn to God and change the way they think and act.’
16.31: “Abraham answered him, ‘If they won’t listen to Moses’ Teachings and the Prophets, they won’t be persuaded even if someone comes back to life.’”

17.1: Yeshua told his disciples, “Situations that cause people to lose their faith are certain to arise. But how horrible it will be for the person who causes someone to lose his faith!
17.2: It would be best for that person to be thrown into the sea with a large stone hung around his neck than for him to cause one of these little ones to lose his faith.
17.3:
So watch yourselves!
“If a believer sins, correct him. If he changes the way he thinks and acts, forgive him.
17.4: Even if he wrongs you seven times in one day and comes back to you seven times and says that he is sorry, forgive him.”
17.5: Then the apostles said to the Lord, “Give us more faith.”
17.6: The Lord said, “If you have faith the size of a mustard seed, you could say to this mulberry tree, ‘Pull yourself up by the roots, and plant yourself in the sea!’ and it would obey you.
17.7: “Suppose someone has a servant who is plowing fields or watching sheep. Does he tell his servant when he comes from the field, ‘Have something to eat’?
17.8: No. Instead, he tells his servant, ‘Get dinner ready for me! After you serve me my dinner, you can eat yours.’
17.9: He doesn’t thank the servant for following orders.
17.10: That’s the way it is with you. When you’ve done everything you’re ordered to do, say, ‘We’re worthless servants. We’ve only done our duty.’”
17.11: Yeshua traveled along the border between Samaria and Galilee on his way to Jerusalem.
17.12: As he went into a village, ten men with a skin disease met him. They stood at a distance
17.13: and shouted, “Yeshua, Teacher, have mercy on us!”
17.14: When he saw them, he told them, “Show yourselves to the priests.” As they went, they were made clean.
17.15: When one of them saw that he was healed, he turned back and praised God in a loud voice.
17.16: He quickly bowed at Yeshua’s feet and thanked him. (The man was a Samaritan.)
17.17: Yeshua asked, “Weren’t ten men made clean? Where are the other nine?
17.18: Only this foreigner came back to praise God.”
17.19: Yeshua told the man, “Get up, and go home! Your faith has made you well.”
17.20:
The Pharisees asked Yeshua when the kingdom of God would come.
He answered them, “People can’t observe the coming of the kingdom of God.
17.21: They can’t say, ‘Here it is!’ or ‘There it is!’ You see, the kingdom of God is within you.”
17.22: Yeshua said to his disciples, “The time will come when you will long to see one of the days of the Son of Man, but you will not see it.
17.23: People will say, ‘There he is!’ or ‘Here he is!’ Don’t run after those people.
17.24: The day of the Son of Man will be like lightning that flashes from one end of the sky to the other.
17.25: But first he must suffer a lot and be rejected by the people of his day.
17.26: “When the Son of Man comes again, the situation will be like the time of Noah.
17.27: People were eating, drinking, and getting married until the day that Noah went into the ship. Then the flood destroyed all of them.
17.28: “The situation will also be like the time of Lot. People were eating, drinking, buying and selling, planting and building.
17.29: But on the day that Lot left Sodom, fire and sulfur rained from the sky and destroyed all of them.
17.30: The day when the Son of Man is revealed will be like that.
17.31: “On that day those who are on the roof shouldn’t come down to get their belongings out of their houses. Those who are in the field shouldn’t turn back.
17.33: Those who try to save their lives will lose them, and those who lose their lives will save them.
17.34: “I can guarantee that on that night if two people are in one bed, one will be taken and the other one will be left.
17.35: Two women will be grinding grain together. One will be taken, and the other one will be left.”
17.37:
They asked him, “Where, Lord?”
Yeshua told them, “Vultures will gather wherever there is a dead body.”

18.1: Yeshua used this illustration with his disciples to show them that they need to pray all the time and never give up.
18.2: He said, “In a city there was a judge who didn’t fear God or respect people.
18.3: In that city there was also a widow who kept coming to him and saying, ‘Give me justice.’
18.4: “For a while the judge refused to do anything. But then he thought, ‘This widow really annoys me. Although I don’t fear God or respect people,
18.5: I’ll have to give her justice. Otherwise, she’ll keep coming to me until she wears me out.’”
18.6: The Lord added, “Pay attention to what the dishonest judge thought.
18.7: Won’t God give his chosen people justice when they cry out to him for help day and night? Is he slow to help them?
18.8: I can guarantee that he will give them justice quickly. But when the Son of Man comes, will he find faith on earth?”
18.9: Yeshua also used this illustration with some who were sure that God approved of them while they looked down on everyone else.
18.10: He said, “Two men went into the temple courtyard to pray. One was a Pharisee, and the other was a tax collector.
18.11: The Pharisee stood up and prayed, ‘God, I thank you that I’m not like other people! I’m not a robber or a dishonest person. I haven’t committed adultery. I’m not even like this tax collector.
18.12: I fast twice a week, and I give you a tenth of my entire income.’
18.13: “But the tax collector was standing at a distance. He wouldn’t even look up to heaven. Instead, he became very upset, and he said, ‘God, be merciful to me, a sinner!’
18.14: “I can guarantee that this tax collector went home with God’s approval, but the Pharisee didn’t. Everyone who honors himself will be humbled, but the person who humbles himself will be honored.”
18.15: Some people brought infants to Yeshua to have him hold them. When the disciples saw this, they told the people not to do that.
18.16: But Yeshua called the infants to him and said, “Don’t stop the children from coming to me! Children like these are part of the kingdom of God.
18.17: I can guarantee this truth: Whoever doesn’t receive the kingdom of God as a little child receives it will never enter it.”
18.18: An official asked Yeshua, “Good Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?”
18.19: Yeshua said to him, “Why do you call me good? No one is good except God.
18.20: You know the commandments: Never commit adultery. Never murder. Never steal. Never give false testimony. Honor your father and your mother.”
18.21: The official replied, “I’ve obeyed all these commandments since I was a boy.”
18.22: When Yeshua heard this, he said to him, “You still need one thing. Sell everything you have. Distribute the money to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then follow me!”
18.23: When the official heard this, he became sad, because he was very rich.
18.24: Yeshua watched him and said, “How hard it is for rich people to enter the kingdom of God!
18.25: Indeed, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to enter the kingdom of God.”
18.26: Those who heard him asked, “Who, then, can be saved?”
18.27: Yeshua said, “The things that are impossible for people to do are possible for God to do.”
18.28: Then Peter said, “We’ve left everything to follow you.”
18.29: Yeshua said to them, “I can guarantee this truth: Anyone who gave up his home, wife, brothers, parents, or children because of the kingdom of God
18.30: will certainly receive many times as much in this life and will receive eternal life in the world to come.”
18.31: Yeshua took the twelve apostles aside and said to them, “We’re going to Jerusalem. Everything that the prophets wrote about the Son of Man will come true.
18.32: He will be handed over to foreigners. They will make fun of him, insult him, spit on him,
18.33: whip him, and kill him. But on the third day he will come back to life.”
18.34: But they didn’t understand any of this. What he said was a mystery to them, and they didn’t know what he meant.
18.35: As Yeshua came near Jericho, a blind man was sitting and begging by the road.
18.36: When he heard the crowd going by, he tried to find out what was happening.
18.37: The people told him that Yeshua from Nazareth was passing by.
18.38: Then the blind man shouted, “Yeshua, Son of David, have mercy on me!”
18.39: The people at the front of the crowd told the blind man to be quiet. But he shouted even louder, “Son of David, have mercy on me!”
18.40: Yeshua stopped and ordered them to bring the man to him. When the man came near, Yeshua asked him,
18.41:
“What do you want me to do for you?”
The blind man said, “Lord, I want to see again.”
18.42: Yeshua told him, “Receive your sight! Your faith has made you well.”
18.43: Immediately, he could see again. He followed Yeshua and praised God. All the people saw this, and they, too, praised God.

19.2: A man named Zacchaeus was there. He was the director of tax collectors, and he was rich.
19.3: He tried to see who Yeshua was. But Zacchaeus was a small man, and he couldn’t see Yeshua because of the crowd.
19.4: So Zacchaeus ran ahead and climbed a fig tree to see Yeshua, who was coming that way.
19.5: When Yeshua came to the tree, he looked up and said, “Zacchaeus, come down! I must stay at your house today.”
19.6: Zacchaeus came down and was glad to welcome Yeshua into his home.
19.7: But the people who saw this began to express disapproval. They said, “He went to be the guest of a sinner.”
19.8: Later, at dinner, Zacchaeus stood up and said to the Lord, “Lord, I’ll give half of my property to the poor. I’ll pay four times as much as I owe to those I have cheated in any way.”
19.9: Then Yeshua said to Zacchaeus, “You and your family have been saved today. You’ve shown that you, too, are one of Abraham’s descendants.
19.10: Indeed, the Son of Man has come to seek and to save people who are lost.”
19.11: Yeshua was getting closer to Jerusalem, and the people thought that the kingdom of God would appear suddenly. While Yeshua had the people’s attention, he used this illustration.
19.12: He said, “A prince went to a distant country to be appointed king, and then he returned.
19.13: Before he left, he called ten of his servants and gave them ten coins. He said to his servants, ‘Invest this money until I come back.’
19.14: “The citizens of his own country hated him. They sent representatives to follow him and say to the person who was going to appoint him, ‘We don’t want this man to be our king.’
19.15: “After he was appointed king, he came back. Then he said, ‘Call those servants to whom I gave money. I want to know how much each one has made by investing.’
19.16: “The first servant said, ‘Sir, the coin you gave me has earned ten times as much.’
19.17: “The king said to him, ‘Good job! You’re a good servant. You proved that you could be trusted with a little money. Take charge of ten cities.’
19.18: “The second servant said, ‘The coin you gave me, sir, has made five times as much.’
19.19: “The king said to this servant, ‘You take charge of five cities.’
19.20: “Then the other servant said, ‘Sir, look! Here’s your coin. I’ve kept it in a cloth for safekeeping because
19.21: I was afraid of you. You’re a tough person to get along with. You take what isn’t yours and harvest grain you haven’t planted.’
19.22: “The king said to him, ‘I’ll judge you by what you’ve said, you evil servant! You knew that I was a tough person to get along with. You knew that I take what isn’t mine and harvest grain I haven’t planted.
19.23: Then why didn’t you put my money in the bank? When I came back, I could have collected it with interest.’
19.24: The king told his men, ‘Take his coin away, and give it to the man who has ten.’
19.25: “They replied, ‘Sir, he already has ten coins.’
19.26: “‘I can guarantee that everyone who has something will be given more. But everything will be taken away from those who don’t have much.
19.27: Bring my enemies, who didn’t want me to be their king. Kill them in front of me.’”
19.28: After Yeshua had given this illustration, he continued on his way to Jerusalem.
19.29: When he came near Bethphage and Bethany at the Mount of Olives (as it was called), Yeshua sent two of his disciples ahead of him.
19.30: He said to them, “Go into the village ahead of you. As you enter, you will find a young donkey tied there. No one has ever sat on it. Untie it, and bring it.
19.31: If anyone asks you why you are untying it, say that the Lord needs it.”
19.32: The men Yeshua sent found it as he had told them.
19.33: While they were untying the young donkey, its owners asked them, “Why are you untying the donkey?”
19.34: The disciples answered, “The Lord needs it.”
19.35: They brought the donkey to Yeshua, put their coats on it, and helped Yeshua onto it.
19.36: As he was riding along, people spread their coats on the road.
19.37: By this time he was coming near the place where the road went down the Mount of Olives. Then the whole crowd of disciples began to praise God for all the miracles they had seen.
19.38:
They shouted joyfully,
“Blessed is the king who comes in the name of the Lord!
    Peace in heaven, and glory in the highest heaven.”
19.39: Some of the Pharisees in the crowd said to Yeshua, “Teacher, tell your disciples to be quiet.”
19.40: Yeshua replied, “I can guarantee that if they are quiet, the stones will cry out.”
19.41: When he came closer and saw the city, he began to cry.
19.42: He said, “If you had only known today what would bring you peace! But now it is hidden, so you cannot see it.
19.43: The time will come when enemy armies will build a wall to surround you and close you in on every side.
19.44: They will level you to the ground and kill your people. One stone will not be left on top of another, because you didn’t recognize the time when God came to help you.”
19.45: Yeshua went into the temple courtyard and began to throw out those who were selling things there.
19.46: He said to them, “Scripture says, ‘My house will be a house of prayer,’ but you have turned it into a gathering place for thieves.”
19.47: Yeshua taught in the temple courtyard every day. The chief priests, the experts in Moses’ Teachings, and the leaders of the people looked for a way to kill him.
19.48: But they could not find a way to do it, because all the people were eager to hear him.

20.1: One day Yeshua was teaching the people in the temple courtyard and telling them the Good News. The chief priests, the experts in Moses’ Teachings, and the leaders came up to him.
20.2: They asked him, “Tell us, what gives you the right to do these things? Who told you that you could do this?”
20.3: Yeshua answered them, “I, too, have a question for you. Tell me,
20.4: did John’s right to baptize come from heaven or from humans?”
20.5: They talked about this among themselves. They said, “If we say, ‘from heaven,’ he will ask, ‘Why didn’t you believe him?’
20.6: But if we say, ‘from humans,’ everyone will stone us to death. They’re convinced that John was a prophet.”
20.7: So they answered that they didn’t know who gave John the right to baptize.
20.8: Yeshua told them, “Then I won’t tell you why I have the right to do these things.”
20.9: Then, using this illustration, Yeshua spoke to the people: “A man planted a vineyard, leased it to vineyard workers, and went on a long trip.
20.10: “At the right time he sent a servant to the workers to obtain from them a share of the grapes from the vineyard. But the workers beat the servant and sent him back with nothing.
20.11: So he sent a different servant. The workers beat him, treated him shamefully, and sent him back with nothing.
20.12: Then he sent a third servant. But they injured this one and threw him out of the vineyard.
20.13: “Then the owner of the vineyard said, ‘What should I do? I’ll send my son, whom I love. They’ll probably respect him.’
20.14: “When the workers saw him, they talked it over among themselves. They said, ‘This is the heir. Let’s kill him so that the inheritance will be ours.’
20.15:
So they threw him out of the vineyard and killed him.
“What will the owner of the vineyard do to them?
20.16:
He will destroy these workers and give the vineyard to others.”
Those who heard him said, “That’s unthinkable!”
20.17:
Then Yeshua looked straight at them and asked, “What, then, does this Scripture verse mean:
‘The stone that the builders rejected
    has become the cornerstone’?
20.18: Everyone who falls on that stone will be broken. If that stone falls on anyone, it will crush that person.”
20.19: The experts in Moses’ Teachings and the chief priests wanted to arrest him right there, but they were afraid of the people. They knew that he had directed this illustration at them.
20.20: So they watched for an opportunity to send out some spies. The spies were to act like sincere religious people. They wanted to catch him saying the wrong thing so that they could hand him over to the governor.
20.21: They asked him, “Teacher, we know that you’re right in what you say and teach. Besides, you don’t play favorites. Rather, you teach the way of God truthfully.
20.22: Is it right for us to pay taxes to the emperor or not?”
20.23: He saw through their scheme, so he said to them,
20.24:
“Show me a coin. Whose face and name is this?”
They answered, “The emperor’s.”
20.25: He said to them, “Well, then give the emperor what belongs to the emperor, and give God what belongs to God.”
20.26: They couldn’t make him say anything wrong in front of the people. His answer surprised them, so they said no more.
20.27: Some Sadducees, who say that people will never come back to life, came to Yeshua. They asked him,
20.28: “Teacher, Moses wrote for us, ‘If a married man dies and has no children, his brother should marry his widow and have children for his brother.’
20.29: There were seven brothers. The first got married and died without having children.
20.30: Then the second brother married the widow,
20.31: and so did the third. In the same way all seven brothers married the widow, died, and left no children.
20.33: Now, when the dead come back to life, whose wife will she be? The seven brothers had married her.”
20.34: Yeshua said to them, “In this world people get married.
20.35: But people who are considered worthy to come back to life and live in the next world will neither marry
20.36: nor die anymore. They are the same as the angels. They are God’s children who have come back to life.
20.37: “Even Moses showed in the passage about the bush that the dead come back to life. He says that the Lord is the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
20.38: He’s not the God of the dead but of the living. In God’s sight all people are living.”
20.39: Some experts in Moses’ Teachings responded, “Teacher, that was well said.”
20.40: From that time on, no one dared to ask him another question.
20.41: Yeshua said to them, “How can people say that the Messiah is David’s son?
20.42:
David says in the book of Psalms,
‘The Lord said to my Lord,
    “Take the highest position in heaven
20.43: until I make your enemies your footstool.” ’
20.44: David calls him Lord. So how can he be his son?”
20.45: While all the people were listening, Yeshua said to the disciples,
20.46: “Beware of the experts in Moses’ Teachings! They like to walk around in long robes and love to be greeted in the marketplaces, to have the front seats in the synagogues and the places of honor at dinners.
20.47: They rob widows by taking their houses and then say long prayers to make themselves look good. The experts in Moses’ Teachings will receive the most severe punishment.”

21.1: Looking up, Yeshua saw people, especially the rich, dropping their gifts into the temple offering box.
21.2: He noticed a poor widow drop in two small coins.
21.3: He said, “I can guarantee this truth: This poor widow has given more than all the others.
21.4: All of these people have given what they could spare. But she, in her poverty, has given everything she had to live on.”
21.5: Some of the disciples were talking about the temple complex. They noted that it was built with fine stones and decorated with beautiful gifts. So Yeshua said,
21.6: “About these buildings that you see—the time will come when not one of these stones will be left on top of another. Each one will be torn down.”
21.7: The disciples asked him, “Teacher, when will this happen? What will be the sign when all this will occur?”
21.8: Yeshua said, “Be careful that you are not deceived. Many will come using my name. They will say, ‘I am he!’ and ‘The time is near.’ Don’t follow them!
21.9: “When you hear of wars and revolutions, don’t be terrified! These things must happen first, but the end will not come immediately.”
21.10: Then Yeshua continued, “Nation will fight against nation and kingdom against kingdom.
21.11: There will be terrible earthquakes, famines, and dreadful diseases in various places. Terrifying sights and miraculous signs will come from the sky.
21.12: “Before all these things happen, people will arrest and persecute you. They will hand you over to their synagogues and put you into their prisons. They will drag you in front of kings and governors because of my name.
21.13: It will be your opportunity to testify to them.
21.14: So make up your minds not to worry beforehand how you will defend yourselves.
21.15: I will give you words and wisdom that none of your enemies will be able to oppose or prove wrong.
21.16: “Even parents, brothers, relatives, and friends will betray you and kill some of you.
21.17: Everyone will hate you because you are committed to me.
21.18: But not a hair on your head will be lost.
21.19: By your endurance you will save your life.
21.20: “When you see armies camped around Jerusalem, realize that the time is near for it to be destroyed.
21.21: Then those of you in Judea should flee to the mountains. Those of you in Jerusalem should leave it. Those of you in the fields shouldn’t go back into them.
21.22: This will be a time of vengeance. Everything that is written about it will come true.
21.23: “How horrible it will be for women who are pregnant or who are nursing babies in those days. Indeed, the land will suffer very hard times, and its people will be punished.
21.24: Swords will cut them down, and they will be carried off into all nations as prisoners. Nations will trample Jerusalem until the times allowed for the nations to do this are over.
21.25: “Miraculous signs will occur in the sun, moon, and stars. The nations of the earth will be deeply troubled and confused because of the roaring and tossing of the sea.
21.26: People will faint as they fearfully wait for what will happen to the world. Indeed, the powers of the universe will be shaken.
21.27: “Then people will see the Son of Man coming in a cloud with power and great glory.
21.28: “When these things begin to happen, stand with confidence! The time when you will be set free is near.”
21.29: Then Yeshua used this story as an illustration. “Look at the fig tree or any other tree.
21.30: As soon as leaves grow on them, you know without being told that summer is near.
21.31: In the same way, when you see these things happen, you know that the kingdom of God is near.
21.32: “I can guarantee this truth: This generation will not disappear until all this takes place.
21.33: The earth and the heavens will disappear, but my words will never disappear.
21.34: “Make sure that you don’t become drunk, hung over, and worried about life. Then that day could suddenly catch you by surprise
21.35: like a trap that catches a bird. That day will surprise all people who live on the earth.
21.36: Be alert at all times. Pray so that you have the power to escape everything that is about to happen and to stand in front of the Son of Man.”
21.37: During the day Yeshua would teach in the temple courtyard. But at night he would go to the Mount of Olives (as it was called) and spend the night there.
21.38: All of the people would get up early to hear him speak in the temple courtyard.

22.1: The Festival of Unleavened Bread, called Passover, was near.
22.2: The chief priests and the experts in Moses’ Teachings were looking for some way to kill Yeshua. However, they were afraid of the people.
22.3: Then Satan entered Judas Iscariot, one of the twelve apostles.
22.4: Judas went to the chief priests and the temple guards and discussed with them how he could betray Yeshua.
22.5: They were pleased and agreed to give him some money.
22.6: So Judas promised to do it. He kept looking for an opportunity to betray Yeshua to them when there was no crowd.
22.7: The day came during the Festival of Unleavened Bread when the Passover lamb had to be killed.
22.8: Yeshua sent Peter and John and told them, “Go, prepare the Passover lamb for us to eat.”
22.9: They asked him, “Where do you want us to prepare it?”
22.10: He told them, “Go into the city, and you will meet a man carrying a jug of water. Follow him into the house he enters.
22.11: Tell the owner of the house that the teacher asks, ‘Where is the room where I can eat the Passover meal with my disciples?’
22.12: He will take you upstairs and show you a large furnished room. Get things ready there.”
22.13: The disciples left. They found everything as Yeshua had told them and prepared the Passover.
22.14: When it was time to eat the Passover meal, Yeshua and the apostles were at the table.
22.15: Yeshua said to them, “I’ve had a deep desire to eat this Passover with you before I suffer.
22.16: I can guarantee that I won’t eat it again until it finds its fulfillment in the kingdom of God.”
22.17: Then he took a cup and spoke a prayer of thanksgiving. He said, “Take this, and share it.
22.18: I can guarantee that from now on I won’t drink this wine until the kingdom of God comes.”
22.19: Then Yeshua took bread and spoke a prayer of thanksgiving. He broke the bread, gave it to them, and said, “This is my body, which is given up for you. Do this to remember me.”
22.20: When supper was over, he did the same with the cup. He said, “This cup that is poured out for you is the new promise made with my blood.”
22.21: “The hand of the one who will betray me is with me on the table.
22.22: The Son of Man is going to die the way it has been planned for him. But how horrible it will be for that person who betrays him.”
22.23: So they began to discuss with each other who could do such a thing.
22.24: Then a quarrel broke out among the disciples. They argued about who should be considered the greatest.
22.25: Yeshua said to them, “The kings of nations have power over their people, and those in authority call themselves friends of the people.
22.26: But you’re not going to be that way! Rather, the greatest among you must be like the youngest, and your leader must be like a servant.
22.27: Who’s the greatest, the person who sits at the table or the servant? Isn’t it really the person who sits at the table? But I’m among you as a servant.
22.28: “You have stood by me in the troubles that have tested me.
22.29: So as my Father has given me a kingdom, I’m giving it to you.
22.30: You will eat and drink at my table in my kingdom. You will also sit on thrones and judge the twelve tribes of Israel.”
22.31: Then the Lord said, “Simon, Simon, listen! Satan has demanded to have you apostles for himself. He wants to separate you from me as a farmer separates wheat from husks.
22.32: But I have prayed for you, Simon, that your faith will not fail. So when you recover, strengthen the other disciples.”
22.33: But Peter said to him, “Lord, I’m ready to go to prison with you and to die with you.”
22.34: Yeshua replied, “Peter, I can guarantee that the rooster won’t crow tonight until you say three times that you don’t know me.”
22.35:
Then Yeshua said to them, “When I sent you out without a wallet, traveling bag, or sandals, you didn’t lack anything, did you?”
“Not a thing!” they answered.
22.36: Then he said to them, “But now, the person who has a wallet and a traveling bag should take them along. The person who doesn’t have a sword should sell his coat and buy one.
22.37: I can guarantee that the Scripture passage which says, ‘He was counted with criminals,’ must find its fulfillment in me. Indeed, whatever is written about me will come true.”
22.38:
The disciples said, “Lord, look! Here are two swords!”
Then Yeshua said to them, “That’s enough!”
22.39: Yeshua went out of the city to the Mount of Olives as he usually did. His disciples followed him.
22.40: When he arrived, he said to them, “Pray that you won’t be tempted.”
22.41: Then he withdrew from them about a stone’s throw, knelt down, and prayed,
22.42: “Father, if it is your will, take this cup of suffering away from me. However, your will must be done, not mine.”
22.43: Then an angel from heaven appeared to him and gave him strength.
22.44: So he prayed very hard in anguish. His sweat became like drops of blood falling to the ground.
22.45: When Yeshua ended his prayer, he got up and went to the disciples. He found them asleep and overcome with sadness.
22.46: He said to them, “Why are you sleeping? Get up, and pray that you won’t be tempted.”
22.47: While he was still speaking to the disciples, a crowd arrived. The man called Judas, one of the twelve apostles, was leading them. He came close to Yeshua to kiss him.
22.48: Yeshua said to him, “Judas, do you intend to betray the Son of Man with a kiss?”
22.49: The men who were with Yeshua saw what was going to happen. So they asked him, “Lord, should we use our swords to fight?”
22.50: One of the disciples cut off the right ear of the chief priest’s servant.
22.51: But Yeshua said, “Stop! That’s enough of this.” Then he touched the servant’s ear and healed him.
22.52: Then Yeshua said to the chief priests, temple guards, and leaders who had come for him, “Have you come out with swords and clubs as if I were a criminal?
22.53: I was with you in the temple courtyard every day and you didn’t try to arrest me. But this is your time, when darkness rules.”
22.54:
So they arrested Yeshua and led him away to the chief priest’s house.
Peter followed at a distance.
22.55: Some men had lit a fire in the middle of the courtyard. As they sat together, Peter sat among them.
22.56: A female servant saw him as he sat facing the glow of the fire. She stared at him and said, “This man was with Yeshua.”
22.57: But Peter denied it by saying, “I don’t know him, woman.”
22.58:
A little later someone else saw Peter and said, “You are one of them.”
But Peter said, “Not me!”
22.59: About an hour later another person insisted, “It’s obvious that this man was with him. He’s a Galilean!”
22.60:
But Peter said, “I don’t know what you’re talking about!”
Just then, while he was still speaking, a rooster crowed.
22.61: Then the Lord turned and looked directly at Peter. Peter remembered what the Lord had said: “Before a rooster crows today, you will say three times that you don’t know me.”
22.62: Then Peter went outside and cried bitterly.
22.63: The men who were guarding Yeshua made fun of him as they beat him.
22.64: They blindfolded him and said to him, “Tell us who hit you.”
22.65: They also insulted him in many other ways.
22.66: In the morning the council of the people’s leaders, the chief priests and the experts in Moses’ Teachings, gathered together. They brought Yeshua in front of their highest court and asked him,
22.67:
“Tell us, are you the Messiah?”
Yeshua said to them, “If I tell you, you won’t believe me.
22.68: And if I ask you, you won’t answer.
22.69: But from now on, the Son of Man will be in the highest position in heaven.”
22.70:
Then all of them said, “So you’re the Son of God?”
Yeshua answered them, “You’re right to say that I am.”
22.71: Then they said, “Why do we need any more testimony? We’ve heard him say it ourselves.”

23.1: Then the entire assembly stood up and took him to Pilate.
23.2: They began to accuse Yeshua by saying, “We found that he stirs up trouble among our people: He keeps them from paying taxes to the emperor, and he says that he is Christ, a king.”
23.3:
Pilate asked him, “Are you the king of the Jews?”
“Yes, I am,” Yeshua answered.
23.4: Pilate said to the chief priests and the crowd, “I can’t find this man guilty of any crime.”
23.5: The priests and the crowd became more forceful. They said, “He stirs up the people throughout Judea with his teachings. He started in Galilee and has come here.”
23.6: When Pilate heard that, he asked if the man was from Galilee.
23.7: When Pilate found out that he was, he sent Yeshua to Herod. Herod ruled Galilee and was in Jerusalem at that time.
23.8: Herod was very pleased to see Yeshua. For a long time he had wanted to see him. He had heard about Yeshua and hoped to see him perform some kind of miracle.
23.9: Herod asked Yeshua many questions, but Yeshua wouldn’t answer him.
23.10: Meanwhile, the chief priests and the experts in Moses’ Teachings stood there and shouted their accusations against Yeshua.
23.11: Herod and his soldiers treated Yeshua with contempt and made fun of him. They put a colorful robe on him and sent him back to Pilate.
23.12: So Herod and Pilate became friends that day. They had been enemies before this.
23.13: Then Pilate called together the chief priests, the rulers, and the people.
23.14: He told them, “You brought me this man as someone who turns the people against the government. I’ve questioned him in front of you and haven’t found this man guilty of the crimes of which you accuse him.
23.15: Neither could Herod. So he sent this man back to us. This man hasn’t done anything to deserve the death penalty.
23.16: So I’m going to have him whipped and set free.”
23.18: The whole crowd then shouted, “Take him away! Free Barabbas for us.”
23.19: (Barabbas had been thrown into prison for his involvement in a riot that had taken place in the city and for murder.)
23.20: But because Pilate wanted to free Yeshua, he spoke to the people again.
23.21: They began yelling, “Crucify him! Crucify him!”
23.22: A third time Pilate spoke to them. He asked, “Why? What has he done wrong? I haven’t found this man deserving of the death penalty. So I’m going to have him whipped and set free.”
23.23: But the crowd pressured Pilate. They shouted that Yeshua had to be crucified, and they finally won.
23.24: Pilate decided to give in to their demand.
23.25: He freed Barabbas, who had been put in prison for rioting and murdering, because that’s what they wanted. But he let them do what they wanted to Yeshua.
23.26: As the soldiers led Yeshua away, they grabbed a man named Simon, who was from the city of Cyrene. Simon was coming into Jerusalem. They laid the cross on him and made him carry it behind Yeshua.
23.27: A large crowd followed Yeshua. The women in the crowd cried and sang funeral songs for him.
23.28: Yeshua turned to them and said, “You women of Jerusalem, don’t cry for me! Rather, cry for yourselves and your children!
23.29: The time is coming when people will say, ‘Blessed are the women who couldn’t get pregnant, who couldn’t give birth, and who couldn’t nurse a child.’
23.30: Then people will say to the mountains, ‘Fall on us!’ and to the hills, ‘Cover us!’
23.31: If people do this to a green tree, what will happen to a dry one?”
23.32: Two others, who were criminals, were led away to be executed with him.
23.33: When they came to the place called The Skull, they crucified him. The criminals were also crucified, one on his right and the other on his left.
23.34:
Then Yeshua said, “Father, forgive them. They don’t know what they’re doing.”
Meanwhile, the soldiers divided his clothes among themselves by throwing dice.
23.35: The people stood there watching. But the rulers were making sarcastic remarks. They said, “He saved others. If he’s the Messiah that God has chosen, let him save himself!”
23.36: The soldiers also made fun of him. They would go up to him, offer him some vinegar,
23.37: and say, “If you’re the king of the Jews, save yourself!”
23.38: A written notice was placed above him. It said, “This is the king of the Jews.”
23.39: One of the criminals hanging there insulted Yeshua by saying, “So you’re really the Messiah, are you? Well, save yourself and us!”
23.40: But the other criminal scolded him: “Don’t you fear God at all? Can’t you see that you’re condemned in the same way that he is?
23.41: Our punishment is fair. We’re getting what we deserve. But this man hasn’t done anything wrong.”
23.42: Then he said, “Yeshua, remember me when you enter your kingdom.”
23.43: Yeshua said to him, “I can guarantee this truth: Today you will be with me in paradise.”
23.44: Around noon darkness came over the entire land and lasted until three in the afternoon.
23.45: The sun had stopped shining. The curtain in the temple was split in two.
23.46: Yeshua cried out in a loud voice, “Father, into your hands I entrust my spirit.” After he said this, he died.
23.47: When an army officer saw what had happened, he praised God and said, “Certainly, this man was innocent!”
23.48: Crowds had gathered to see the sight. But when all of them saw what had happened, they cried and returned to the city.
23.49: All his friends, including the women who had followed him from Galilee, stood at a distance and watched everything.
23.50: There was a good man who had God’s approval. His name was Joseph. He was a member of the Jewish council,
23.51: but he had not agreed with what they had done. He was from the Jewish city of Arimathea, and he was waiting for the kingdom of God.
23.52: He went to Pilate and asked for the body of Yeshua.
23.53: After he took it down from the cross, he wrapped it in linen. Then he laid the body in a tomb cut in rock, a tomb in which no one had ever been buried.
23.54: It was Friday, and the day of worship was just beginning.
23.55: The women who had come with Yeshua from Galilee followed closely behind Joseph. They observed the tomb and how his body was laid in it.
23.56: Then they went back to the city and prepared spices and perfumes. But on the day of worship they rested according to the commandment.

24.1: Very early on Sunday morning the women went to the tomb. They were carrying the spices that they had prepared.
24.2: They found that the stone had been rolled away from the tomb.
24.3: When they went in, they did not find the body of the Lord Yeshua.
24.4: While they were puzzled about this, two men in clothes that were as bright as lightning suddenly stood beside them.
24.5:
The women were terrified and bowed to the ground.
The men asked the women, “Why are you looking among the dead for the living one?
24.6: He’s not here. He has been brought back to life! Remember what he told you while he was still in Galilee.
24.7: He said, ‘The Son of Man must be handed over to sinful people, be crucified, and come back to life on the third day.’”
24.8: Then the women remembered what Yeshua had told them.
24.9: The women left the tomb and went back to the city. They told everything to the eleven apostles and all the others.
24.10: The women were Mary from Magdala, Joanna, and Mary (the mother of James). There were also other women with them. They told the apostles everything.
24.11: The apostles thought that the women’s story didn’t make any sense, and they didn’t believe them.
24.12: But Peter got up and ran to the tomb. He bent down to look inside and saw only the strips of linen. Then he went away, wondering what had happened.
24.13: On the same day, two of Yeshua’s disciples were going to a village called Emmaus. It was about seven miles from Jerusalem.
24.14: They were talking to each other about everything that had happened.
24.15: While they were talking, Yeshua approached them and began walking with them.
24.16: Although they saw him, they didn’t recognize him.
24.17:
He asked them, “What are you discussing?”
They stopped and looked very sad.
24.18: One of them, Cleopas, replied, “Are you the only one in Jerusalem who doesn’t know what has happened recently?”
24.19:
“What happened?” he asked.
They said to him, “We were discussing what happened to Yeshua from Nazareth. He was a powerful prophet in what he did and said in the sight of God and all the people.
24.20: Our chief priests and rulers had him condemned to death and crucified.
24.21: We were hoping that he was the one who would free Israel. What’s more, this is now the third day since everything happened.
24.22: Some of the women from our group startled us. They went to the tomb early this morning
24.23: and didn’t find his body. They told us that they had seen angels who said that he’s alive.
24.24: Some of our men went to the tomb and found it empty, as the women had said, but they didn’t see him.”
24.25: Then Yeshua said to them, “How foolish you are! You’re so slow to believe everything the prophets said!
24.26: Didn’t the Messiah have to suffer these things and enter into his glory?”
24.27: Then he began with Moses’ Teachings and the Prophets to explain to them what was said about him throughout the Scriptures.
24.28: When they came near the village where they were going, Yeshua acted as if he were going farther.
24.29: They urged him, “Stay with us! It’s getting late, and the day is almost over.” So he went to stay with them.
24.30: While he was at the table with them, he took bread and blessed it. He broke the bread and gave it to them.
24.31: Then their eyes were opened, and they recognized him. But he vanished from their sight.
24.32: They said to each other, “Weren’t we excited when he talked with us on the road and opened up the meaning of the Scriptures for us?”
24.33: That same hour they went back to Jerusalem. They found the eleven apostles and those who were with them gathered together.
24.34: They were saying, “The Lord has really come back to life and has appeared to Simon.”
24.35: Then the two disciples told what had happened on the road and how they had recognized Yeshua when he broke the bread.
24.36: While they were talking about what had happened, Yeshua stood among them. He said to them, “Peace be with you!”
24.37: They were terrified, and thought they were seeing a ghost.
24.38: He asked them, “Why are you afraid? Why do you have doubts?
24.39: Look at my hands and feet, and see that it’s really me. Touch me, and see for yourselves. Ghosts don’t have flesh and bones, but you can see that I do.”
24.40: As he said this, he showed them his hands and feet.
24.41: The disciples were overcome with joy and amazement because this seemed too good to be true. Then Yeshua asked them, “Do you have anything to eat?”
24.42: They gave him a piece of broiled fish.
24.43: He took it and ate it while they watched him.
24.44: Then he said to them, “These are the words I spoke to you while I was still with you. I told you that everything written about me in Moses’ Teachings, the Prophets, and the Psalms had to come true.”
24.45: Then he opened their minds to understand the Scriptures.
24.46: He said to them, “Scripture says that the Messiah would suffer and that he would come back to life on the third day.
24.47: Scripture also says that by the authority of Yeshua people would be told to turn to God and change the way they think and act so that their sins will be forgiven. This would be told to people from all nations, beginning in the city of Jerusalem.
24.48: You are witnesses to these things.
24.49: “I’m sending you what my Father promised. Wait here in the city until you receive power from heaven.”
24.50: Then Yeshua took them to a place near Bethany. There he raised his hands and blessed them.
24.51: While he was blessing them, he left them and was taken to heaven.
24.52: The disciples worshiped him and were overjoyed as they went back to Jerusalem.
24.53: They were always in the temple, where they praised God.
